reviews.review: Exciting. Baphuon temple is a great and requisite temple with sophisticated designs and structure. People usually go there to explore a feeling of inner peace, since when you get there, you would feel no interrupted and feel relaxed. A hidden God is on the wall if you notice thoroughly. That is a great place and can make you excited as well.

Children under 12 are not allowed to climb. But they are allowed all the way up the TA KEO which is almost as steep. The view from the top is breathtaking and because of the off-putting climb, there are fewer people.

Good historical site to see. Baphuon Temple is part of Angkor Thom and is a huge rectangular building, requiring the climbing up of some pretty steep stairs. At the elevated levels the view is quite good. It is necessary to note where one goes up and to try to get down at the same place (down the same stairs) because going down at another location could get you confused. It is very large and takes a while to walk around once.
Nice Temple. This temple is part of Ankoor Wat Temple and very unique. Temples are build using stones. Good to visit with multiple times.

Built on Sand. The Baphuon is a huge temple near the more famous Bayon temple, but as it was built in the 11th Century it predates it by 200 years.Originally built as a Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, it was converted to a Buddhist temple in the 15th Century.The Baphuon was built on sand and was inherently unstable from the beginning, which goes a long way to explaining its sorry state of repair compared to many of the other monuments at the Angkor Archaeological Park. Attempts have been made to restore parts of the temple, but it is a mammoth task.One of the features to look for is a massive reclining Buddha which lies across the entire western wall of the temple. It is also in a sorry state of repair, so you have to look closely and use your imagination to work out its dimensions and shape.

Temple climbing. This temple requires some stamina as you have to climb up some stairs. At the top, you can see some beautiful views around compound.One thing to be aware of is there might be some strangers trying to explain things to you here and there. Please ignore them and dont follow their instructions, At the end of the very brief and pointless "guidance", they will ask for some money. It is definitely not worth the money for their poor service. Just be careful of it
Well worth visiting. A must see among with many other temple ruins in this area. If you are lucky it is not too crowded. Bring your guide book and take your time.

Impressive temple. The view of the temple as you approach along the long walkway is very imposing and rather different from some of the other Angkor temples. My husband went into the temple and the views from the top were definitely worth the climb.....but beware: this temple is not open to children under the age of 12, which our two miniature explorers found a bit disappointing.

good view. A good place to explore, but those with leg sick, older, child or less stamina, please avoid this route. Slanting and long staircase from level 1 to level 3, level 4 closed. Nice view from top.

Spend a little time here.... Even if you are pressed for time, you can still squeeze this temple in your itinerary since it's along the way to other big temples. Marvel at the foot bridge before reaching the temple. I find the ruins to be nice back drop for a photo shoot, too.

Another enjoyable site!. If you don't mind walking and climbing, and if you aren't already "templed out", then you have to add this one to your list! All of the temples in the Angkor area are worth visiting, and if you have a guide, even better - the stories in the carvings make it a worthwhile stop!

Impressive, close to Bayon. Those ruins are a short walk from Bayon. Refresh yourself with a fruit smoothie on the way, and head to there with energy enough to climb the steep stairs that lead to the top of the pyramid (take care to not fall). It is interesting to know that on ancient times this pyramid rivalized with Bayon as the most impressive temple in the area.

Good Physical Challenge. This was one of my favorite temples in the area. The bridge walk to the main structure was a nice stroll. The stairways to the top of the temple were a bit more of a challenge. The structure has a good feeling about it and helps one appreciate the effort it took to put such a building together.
Shouldn't miss. Yeap, it is great. Unique experince that one should not miss. You will not be dissapointed... Amazing place.
Huge Temple. Long walkway leads up to this beautiful temple. Steep stairs to get to the top but worth the effort to see the magnificent views.

Must do temple. this is a must view area for a photography I had some GREAT shots here early morning. So start here away from the crowds While many are out front of ankor wat this is a great area to get some shots early.
Worth a visit. Generally once you buy your ticket for Angkor Watt you can travel to these other attractions on the same ticket, so take them in as they all have something to offer

Surprisingly beautiful. When I was figuring out which temples to visit, a guidebook I was using didn't list Baphuon as a priority. I ended up stopping by on the way to Bayon, and wow. I'm so glad I did.The walkway to the temple is a spectacle in and of itself, and the main level inside of the temple has some interesting features, including the rock stools (that's what I call them, anyway). The view of the grounds from the highest accessible level was breathtaking.After being out and about for the whole day, I'd been a bit tired, but Baphuon woke me right up and reminded me: Dude. You're in Angkor.Don't pass it up!
Lovely temple. Another gem of a temple in Angkor Thom that's well worth spending time in. Really beautiful architecture.

My favourite among the 4-5 temples that I visited. Baphuon Temple is a great sight in comparison to the more well-known temples in Angkor Thom and the surrounding region, because it has less people and a FANTASTIC view at the top! My tip is to start at the front, walk down the elevated processional walkway (great for catching a cool photo of orange-clad monks hurrying down it) and admire the grounds in front, then find your way to the top. When I went, I was the only one at the top for several minutes, and the view of the pounds, processional walkway, and the building itself was the best one I had among the ruins of Siem Reap!

Amazing climb for amzing clicks. Quite an experience walking the long path leading up to the temple, the steep stairs climbing up, taking some excellent pictures and catching some quite rest in the shade in a corner

Impressive temple-mountain. Coming just after a visit of the Bayon, what is striking is: much less tourists and more rustic wall decoration. The steps to the higher platforms are so steep that guards will prevent access to children less than 12 years old. The views as you ascend gets better and better and the whole visit is rewarding. At the end of the circuit you’ll pass by the huge Reclining Buddha, barely visible in the supporting wall of the (ruined) pyramid.

So very pretty. All of the temples in Siem Reap are truly extraordinary and Baphuon Temple was no exception. There are a lot of stairs at this temple, but even if stairs were a problem for you then the landscape views from afar are worth the visit.

Don't Miss out on this one!. A lot of people might miss out on this one as there are other more famous attractions within the ancient city of Ankor Thom. This temple is one of the most difficult to restore as the foundations of this were largely destroyed when they tried to convert this Shiva temple into a Buddhist temple in 15th century. You can observe a reclining Buddha that was attempted to mark this transition. Amazingly steep steps lead you all the way to the top and are a great workout. The size of each step is also astonishingly small .
beautiful. walk there from bayon and admire the elephants at the terrace. recently restored and very different style from angkor watt

Remember you have to wear a nice uniform.. I and my wife live in siem reap. We enjoyed this temple very much. Nice place to see in Angkor Thom temples. This temple is required you to wear long clothes. Should be under you knee and on your bowl.

Beautiful temple - brace yourself for the near vertical climb . This temple is part of the Angkor Thom complex and you will see it if you take the small temple tour. It is connected by a stone terrace to the terraces of the elephants and leper king. It's a three tiered temple. There are stairs which are nearly vertical so be careful and don't wear flip flops. One thing I remember vividly is all the dragonflies floating around. Thousands of them. It was hypnotic.

Worth sparing some time . Part of Angkor Thom complex, this temple is not so famous, not frequently visited compared to its neighbor. It's a shame since you can go on top and have a nice view, apart from this, there is a very pleasant forrest walk to another one just north from Baphuon.

Put it on Your List of Things To See. Fascinating stone carvings produced many centuries before power tools were invented. Try to go with a guide who can set the historical context and provide an explanation of the carvings.
Good temple. unusually shaped building with nice views. Lovely walkway to get to it through ponds. set back from other larger temples but still lovely.
Another great temple must see. Beautiful temple, It has lots of very steep stairs but it wasn't too hard to climb, beautiful view from the top, visited right after Bayon, definitely worth it!

Wonderful Mesmerizing Pyramidal Construction--Worth Visit. Baphuon temple ,originall built dedicated to Hindu God Shiva, will be the second spot in Angkor Thom Complex after visiting Bayon Temple . the Baphuom Temple Complex is fantastically built in a pyramidal structure the long path walk way from main entrance leading the temple is beautifully built in a elevated platform . There is a swimming pool tank at the left side of the walk way to harvest water during the ancient regime. The temple is so precisely engineered in such a manner the structure's base is built heavily and broadened in a three tier -structure , Its requires a knee breaking job to climb the pinnacle of the temple top crest , where we can take some of the breath taking views and photograph of the temple tombs , leapers. At the rear side of the temple we can see a huge reclining statue of Bhudda , which is simply amazing and the spectacular construction of the face of Buddha by assembling huge stones and carving it but it is incomplete . The temple has been restored using Anastylosis method. Most of the temple rumbled and collapsed stones was dismantled and the hundreds of thousands of stones laid out and numbered and re-assembled and erected to complete the structure . The unstable base of the monument was reinforced. Several decades of restorations took place and the Baphuon was opened to the public . Its really a marvelous engineering that Khmer King Udayadityavarman II has evolved centuries ago in Erecting such a magnificent Three-tired temple in 11 th century.
Beautiful temple!!!. This was not my favorite temple to visit however they all deserve a visit. It is incredible to have such a complex centuries old construction.
You will see it.... You will see it as part of Angkor Tom...it is part of any standard tour...so it gets the same review.
Beautiful. I'm such a sucker for architecture site and temple and for me, every temple is worth the visit and if you need to climb to get to the top, go climb and see the view yourself.

Worth a visit. Much quieter than main temples. Set in beautiful surroundings. Much restoration to do as dismantled and then records of where stones to go were destroyed by Khymer Rouge. Many dangerous stairs but worth the climb to top. Lovely walk around temple.
Simply beautiful. This is a simple but beauiful temple. Never miss this site. Great for photo ops. Hope you visit Siem Reap when it's not too hot.

Baphuon Temple at Angkor Tom. This temple is near to the Bayon Temple. This temple is surrounded by many big trees. To reach the top, you need to climb using the wood ladder and you must be careful. On the top, you can see the beautiful nature around this temple.

Giant Pyramid of South East Asia... not for a rainy day!. The Baphuon Temple is in the heart of Angkor Tom. This should be visited after the Bayon temple. The climb here is steep, and proper shoes are required.Do not visit this attraction on a rainy day as you will be sorely disappointed. The slippery nature of the climb makes it dangerous to attempt this on a rainy day. I was disappointed for not being able to climb due to the rain.

Fantastic!. When I visited Bayon, I was also able to visit Baphuon, that is located on the northwest side of Bayon. You can go up to the higher level as they have provided timber steeps that make the climbing easier. It is a fantastic view fro the top and a must do climb. when hot is very tiring but carry plenty of water.

mesmerizing. surrounded by the forest with their sky scrapper trees this temple stands majestically amidst it. the steps are steep and is exciting to climb it. the view form the top is mesmerising. soak in the environment as much as you can!
suprising. first thought was a pile of rubble but opens up to the amazing hidden secrets in history..look out for the squirrels

One of the temples to see if you're checking out Bayon.. Looks majestic especially when viewed from the walkway leading to the temple. The view from the top is glorious although the steps going there are plenty and kind of steep.The only thing I didn't like is that you can't go back the way you came in once you're at the top because you have to exit through the opposite direction. This is a bit of an irritation when you've been walking all day and plan on seeing just this particular attraction but is forced to go through all the other temples.
Temple. Awesome to see & appreciate just amazing what was built so long ago without machinery to assist worth the time to visit.
Lovely temple. This is a lovely and ancient temple in the Angkor complex. We enjoyed walking through, and we very much enjoyed seeing history come to life. Great photo ops, too.

Walk along the causeway!. One of my other favourite sites was built by Udayadityavarman II in 1060 as his state temple. It's current state of being something of a ruin should not elude from how important this temple pyramid was. I particularly liked walking across the causeway supported by many fine pillars. A word of warning, climbing to the top and back down again is quite a feat as the stairway is very very narrow in length.
Climb to the top!. Worth the climb up to the top of this just for the view. It is very steep though, so bring good shoes!!

more temples more rocks... on a hot and humid day, the temples do loose their historic lustre, and starts to feel like a severe excercise in endurance and dehydration. Hats / water / good shoes.. all required to climb through here to be rewarded with stunning views of the complex and the creeping jungle.
Don't rush. Take your time and don't miss any of it. I wander off alone and the feeling of the past is so present. The jungle is alive, the temples are amazing.

Finally restored, now one of the more interesting structures at Angkor. Baphuon used to be more or less a big mess of looted stones that seemed to follow no particular structure. Now it has been restored and turns out to be one of the most interesting complexes of central Angkor. Go there in the late afternoon and you will enjoy the special light, and no other tourists around you!

Neat recently restore temple!. Baphuon is a short walk from Angkor Thom, so we went there right after. While Angkor Thom was more spectacular, we really enjoyed climbing this temple and walking around it! A great stop to make!
Worth see it!. Another great temple worth to see it! You can climb high enough for nice view. Just enjoy the visit and climb up the temple

Right beside Bayon, dont miss it! Another temple climb challenge!. It is just 3mins walk from Bayon. On your long walkway into temple, you can see local kids happily playing in pond (now become their play pool)..you instantly feel local ( and happy) too! Do wear appropriate clothing, the guard religiously checking my short sleeves whether length was too short! Strictly no bare shoulders and no shorts above knee. I saw visitors asked to leave and its such a pity, cuz the temple top was amazing.

My personal favorite of so many gorgeous temples. It's the Wandering Yank here. Mrs. Yank and I spent 3 wonderful days touring the Angkor area. We saw all of the best-known temples, plus several off the beaten track (thank you, our excellent guide). Why was this my favorite? It wasn't the fact that it wasn't nearly as crowded as adjacent Bayon, although that was a very good thing. It wasn't the view from the top of the stairs, although it was very rewarding. It was the outline of the reclining Buddha which one can only see near the exit. It was almost eerie, and a reminder of the stages this complex has gone through over hundreds of years. Very cool.2 thumbs way up!

Huge pyramid-like temple accessed from a terrace risen from empty pool. It is a huge and amazing temple of pyramid style. It is accessed from a long terraced path which is used to serve as a bridge on a pool of water. The stairs to the top are very steep but there is a newly built wooden steps, less steep, on one side. Highly recommended. Do note, there was a local boy trying to collect signature of tourist. I doubt he was trying to beg. Say no thanks, and ignore him.

Baphuon temple. considered to be one of the grandest of the angkor temples, Baphuon was a hindu temple. it can be approached by a raised walkway and has four gateways decorated with bas reliefs depicting scenes from the hindu mythology of ramayana and mahabharata.
Huge site.. Baphuon Temple is a very big site. There are simply so many fabulous temples in this huge area. All of them truly spectacular.

I enjoyed the reclining budah and my wife loved the child free view from the top!. So this is not the most beautiful of temples in the area but it still has presence. You could easily take a decision not to spend the time walking to it and or up it, but both are worthwhile. Given the stairs etc this was not a child friendly temple and in actual fact they were not aloud up. However the kids and spent time exploring the surrounds and really loved it - from the back their is a huge reclining budah that you could easily miss if you didn't know it was there. My wife on the other hand climbed to the top. She talked of it being extremely peaceful and serene with a beautiful view of the jungle canopy. She said there were butterflies and she enjoyed it very much. Id say its one of the understated temples of the area, right near some of the favourites so worth the investment of an additional 30 minutes to check it out.
In Angkor Thom. If you are already visiting the ancient city of Angkor Thom then it is worth seeing this temple. It has a 'pyramid' style and has undergone a great deal of restoration.

Not my favorite, steep climbing. We went to this temple directly after Bayon (it's right next door) and I have to say, it was certainly my least favorite temple. It's on the small side, and there's not much to see. That being said, I definitely say "go!" if the weather is on the average side - we had just spent a long time at Bayon and were totally overheated, and Bayon is so grand and stunning that going directly here in 100+ degree heat in direct sunlight was not the best time. Also, a minor warning: There are a decent amount of steps in the temple, which wouldn't be as much of an issue if they weren't so steep. One of my friends chose to climb them on "all fours," whereas I needed to hold onto both railings to feel secure. The way up is steep, but keep in mind the way down is an identical set of stairs - you need to take them very slowly and carefully or you could easily slip and fall. We are all in our 20s and this was manageable for us, but could be bad for young children and older people.

Baphuon Temple. This temple is situated inside of Angkor Thom and is an awesome temple to visit. It has a lot of very steep steps so if you don't have good footing you should definitely take care when climbing the steps.The view from the top of Baphuon temple is breathtaking and be sure to go round the back to see the awesome reclining Buddha statue. you may miss it because it is not an actual statue but built into the temple itself.
Just go!. Love! Love love! This place is a must see, for one time pass fee, you get to see as much temples as you want. Everything is amazing!

Active temple. Over 12s only because of steep steps. Guards also ensure no bare knees and no bare shoulders for men and women since this is an active temple.Not so much to see at the temple, but good views of the surroundings.

Still worth a visit. It belongs to group of temples in Angkor Thom and worth to visit as well. You will have a nice walk from Bayon temple. This small temple is opposite to Phimeanakas, located in Angkor Thom northwest of the Bayon temples, to get the bigger temple Phimeanakas you will pass Baphuon first. If you stood on top of Phimeanakas you'll have a nice view of the Baphuon temple. This temple was built around 1150 AD by King Udai Adityavarman II, he dedicated the temple to the Hindu god Shiva. In the 20th century a large part of the temple collapsed, inter alia earthquakes. In 1960 there has been an attempt to rebuild the temple, but when this was not allowed by the Khmer regime. They have made a second attempt in 1996, but this failed. In 2003 it managed and restored much of the temple. As archaeologists did not have the location of all the stones not everything could be restored.

Brilliant. See this as part of a tour of all the temples, such as Angkor Wat, Bayon and Ta Prohm. We visited them all in one day with a private guide. It could easily be spread over 2 or even 3 days. I thoroughly recommend having a guide as it adds a lot you might otherwise miss out on.
lots of stairs. lot of stairs to get on a top so if you are lazy or have problems with your healt condition just look at this one from the street
Looks similar. Once you've seen the main Angkor temple, the others are very similar. The museum has very good preserved and labelled statues.

A large temple located in Angkor Thom. Should be on your to do list after Angkor war. Angkor Thom has several major temples (Bayon, Phimeankas, Elephant Terrace and more) and sites and temples and is well worth investing your time at this site.

Amazing architecture. This was but one of the twelve or so temples we visited over a three day period. This was one where the dress code was policed so my daughter and I couldn't go n. We walked around the back and waited for the remainder of our party and had a good view of the lying down Buddha.

Interesting. We were too exhausted to go inside this temple but it was really nice to look at from a far under a shade of the tree. Per our guide, the place does not have sculptures unlike others. We were contented looking around at it, observing people and monks walking around.
Amazing. Came upon the section of the Temples on our tour of Angkor Wat and Thom, beautifully sculptured, which fascinates the mind. Well worth visiting this part of the site

Nice Temple. A really big temple just across the elephant terrace. One of the nicest temple in Angkor Thom. You can just walk from Bayon to here, and ask your tuk2 driver to pick you up at elephant terrace just like what I did

Magnificent!. This particular Temple was very impressive. The sheer size of it and the climb to the top was epic, especially in the heat... And i was there early morning. One of my favourites for sure in the whole complex.

wonderful. Great example of the type of temples in Angkor our ramrook driver was so knowledgeable he recommended we stop her , worth the time , plenty of photo opportunities and like all other temples walking and climbing steps is on the cards.

No kids inside the temple. This was apparently one of the most spectacular temples in its heyday but only adults are allowed in now due to safety precautions so we admired it from the 200m long elevated walkway. We liked the jigsaw restoration story of Baphuon so was disappointed my 8 yro couldn't go inside. Its called the world largest 3d jigsaw because it was totally dismantled piece by piece (300,000 blocks) as part of the restoration process in 1960 but due to the civil war the project was abandoned for 25 years and the plans were lost. In 1996 they started again and took 16 years to fit all the pieces back together !

Simple yet mesmerising. The Baphuon Temple is a Hindu Temple and I was told that it has inspired the creators of the then-famous iPhone game, Temple Run. As I walked into the temple, I am able to imagine where the creators got their imagination from. There is a platform towards the temple which is surrounded by water and there are trees surrounding the building. This temple is smaller and has simpler artwork compared to the Bayon Temple. As you are climbing up the tower, be sure to watch your step and make sure you wear decently during your visit.

One of our favorite Angkor temples. This was one of our favorite temples in the Angkor complex. Maybe because it wasn't as crowded as the others. Maybe because it was so tall and we practically climbed to the top. In any case, if you're close to it, I recommend spending some time at this one.
Amazing Temple....... This is a very beautiful and amazing looking temple. This temple is large and well preserved for the age. Definitely a must see with beautiful design and architecture.

Children under 12 not allowed!. I am not able to review the temple itself as I was not allowed in with my children. This was my own fault, as I had not researched this particular temple and we simply stopped on a whim on the way back from the other temples we had planned to see. I am giving a 2 star review only to help others from making the same mistake. Do not plan to go unless your kids are 12+. Our boys were very disappointed.

not as amazing as the Bayon, but well worth a visit. Very interesting to see. This temple is at this days a working temple, so children and pregnant woman may not enter. Every visitor need to be well dressed (no shorts ore naked shoulders). It's a climb to reach the central temple, but it is worth to do so.

absolute must to visit. Take your camera and wear good walking shoes, there's lots of walking, we went early morning, so as to miss the heat of the day, well worth it, and dont forget water you, ll need it.

Amazing Scenery and Good Photo Spot. It's high temple and you must climb steep steps, even they already constructing wooden steps. The original steps will be almost impossible to step up. It's located next to Bayon Temple, so you just need walk a few to reach it.If you came here at summer, make sure you're well hydrated since the site are big and the weather is very hot and dry.

Amazing view from top of this temple. One of the few famous temples inside Angkor Wat temple complex, just behind Bayon temple.Quite a steep ascent to the top of the temple, go slow, steps are narrow and steep. Once at the top, the view is amazing, worth the effort. Though the temple is surrounded by nice greenery, however at the top of the temple it is quite sunny and it is difficult to stay long without cap/ umbrella. Comfortable walking shoes are recommended, high heels are certainly a no no. Descent from the top is equally steep, some people prefer walking backwards down, so plan your backpacks and hand held items accordingly as both the hands might be required for backward descent. It is difficult for young children, parents should accompany them all the time. Ticket in included in Angkor Wat temple complex pass.
Amazing view. You have to climb up very steep steps to get to the top but it's worth it. The view on top is amazing.
Baphuon. My favourite temple in the Angkor Thom complex. You can climb to the very top and survey the sights. The steps to the top are quite steep but worth it.

A different temple from Ankor Thom. A different temple from Ankor Thom that deserves the tourists attention as much as Bayon temple. It is the only temple where tourists are not allowed if knees and shoulders are not covered. My wife and many others had only a "limited" T shirt with short sleeves so they were simply not allowed inside. On the back side a very interesting reclining Buddha is built in the wall.
One of my favourites. The promenade up to the temple is impressive and the view from the top is not too shabby. Not as crowded as some of the other temples which makes it all the more enjoyable.

I found the walk in to be the best part.. I visited in January which is the dry season and I don't know if this is ever full of water like the elevated walk would make you think it may have been - but that would very impressive to see. I enjoyed the stroll up on the elevated walk and you can climb to the top and enjoy a view of the surroundings below but I honestly found it a little underwhelming up top. The stairs are very steep and while I hustled down them several older or scared people where taking quite a bit of time making there way up and down - could be a problem if it was crowded.

Baphuon Temple. Temple has an impressive promenade leading up to it. Most impressive feature is the shape of a reclining buddha around the west side of the temple. One really have to focus on it to see the outline. Good portion of temple was out of bounds, however still an interesting site. Temple located within Royal compounds.

Climb a mountain!. A very impressive temple in the Angkor Thom complex and one that you can climb too! The views from the top are pretty impressive and as others have said make sure you dress appropriately.There is supposed to be one way up and one way down so please make sure you read the signs and don't be one of those tourists who goes up the down stairs and causes a jam. On your way out don't forgot to see the huge sleeping Buddha on the backside of the temple！

Do not Go there to Try to Watch the Sunset!. The word is out that this is one of the best places to watch the sunset. The result, amusement park type lines of people waiting to get a view of the sunset. Too crowded & a fairly long walk uphill to get to the coveted, best sunset spot. You probably won't get in unless you're willing to camp out a few hours before sunset. Don't waste your time.

Quieter and really enjoyable. I really enjoyed visiting here if only for the fact that there were far fewer other visitors than the other major sites. The temple is in a fairly ruined state there is still plenty to see and you can get a good impression of what it would have been like. From the entrance there is a long promenade up to the pyramid of the temple which is fully accessible to climb. With there being fewer other visitors you get the opportunity to find your own space.The exit is at the rear and the return path takes you around the outer wall of the temple through the trees. On the one hand it's a bit of a trek in the heat but, equally, it's quite a pleasant walk.

Strict dress code, a lot of climbing, but one of my favourites. We went to almost all of the temples in the Angkor Wat area, so I think it's right to say that this temple has one of the highest staircases in the area. There are 2 tall flights of steps, and it's a steep climb up. It's a good challenge if you're acrophobic. We didn't read up on this temple, so it was a pleasant surprise to discover that the entire temple was a reclining Buddha when viewed from the back, after climbing down. Do note that the dress code is very strict - we sat near the entrance when taking a rest, and many female tourists were turned away. Some tried to wear long skirts in front of the guards, but they were still denied entry. Best to cover up shoulders and knees before going near the entrance (and the guards). Male tourists were also denied entry when they wore mid-thigh shorts/FBTs.

Impression after impression. The Angkor Thom area generates impression after impression. After the extensive visit to the Boyon Temple, the next visit of the Angkor Thom tour was to the Wat Baphuon. The Wat Baphuon is an impressive temple, but with very steep steps. The size and architecture is a bit overwhelming. See my picture.

A steep climb, brilliant views, strict clothing policy, calming and dragon flies at the top!. This was a surprise for me, I really enjoyed this temple on the way to Bayon Temple. In fact I preferred it to the over crowded Bayon Temple. A steep climb and I couldn't believe the butterflies and dragon flies. It was such a calming experience at the level of the trees and wonderful views and I could have stayed all day. Stunning and a must climb, although scary coming back down again. Elephant terrace is so close too :-)

Not unmissable . Part of our tour of Angkor Thom, we went to have a look here. Unfortunately, my girlfriend couldn't get in (scarf over bare shoulders is not allowed, so I went in for a quick run. The temple is not exceptional, not too much decoration, but the view from the top is nice.

Mighty and daunting. This is pyramidal in shape. The steps are very steep and not to be recommended to the elderly and to children. And yet, we, in our seventies, managed it very well. Do visit the Terrace of the Elephants and the Leper King nearby.

A good climb. The stairs which lead to the temple was quite steep. Children under 12 are not allowed to enter. I personally enjoy visiting Baphuon, though 30min-1hr was quite enough.If you have a bad knee, or have a fear of height, maybe you can skip this place.
Temple mountain. Situated inside Angkor Thom, this temple has scenes carved in small squares. Unfortunately most of them are faintly visible due to deterioration and poor upkeep.

Remember to dress "properly". Amazing structure, absolutely stunning spot for photos, comparatively less crowded (we were there at around noon), but very very strict dress code - girls cover your shoulders, no vest, no shorts, must cover your knees. Our guide Kheng Yon reminded us about this and I got a skirt from the local shop for 5 usd. We bumped into an Italian girl who was wearing shorts and vest, and was turned away by the guards :( luckily she has got a sweater with her, therefore I lend her my skirt - ta daa the guard was finally happy to let her in! Strict strict strict code here

Make sure to visit the back of the temple. A simple temple compared to the others but definitely worth a visit.Take the walk to the top of the temple and go around to the back to see the entire layout. Not many people visit here since it doesn't seem like there is much to see from the entrance but they are missing out. Don't be one of the masses and pass this by.Take in all the sights around the temple to enjoy it fully.

Simple but beautiful . This temple lacks the carvings of other temples but is still worth a visit. You will have to climb a lot of steep steps to get to the top, but it gives you nice view of the whole complex. The reclining Bhudda near the exit is pretty incredible.The temple closes at 5pm. When we arrived at 4:45 we were not allowed in and had to come back another day.

Angkor Tom. It was raining again so I did not spend as much time as I might have. Also, most say to visit this temple FIrST. I did not follow their advice, and was not up to a lot of exploring by this time. I did find the carvings fascinating and the altars colorful. (some set up inside-not large.)
Great. Another overlooked temple it is wonderful, albeit, there is some considerable climbing. It has a rather different feel from Angkor.

Strict Jobsworth At The Front Gate. Be sure to adhere to the dress code as, regardless of your gender the guard will not allow you access if you are not dressed appropriately. This happens no where else in the entire Angkor area but this guy deems it necessary to put himself in the way of your enjoyment on what could potentially be your only day to enjoy this temple.That being said there is something cathartic about seeing a man unable to gain access to a temple, this hasn't happened anywhere else in SE Asia to date.I went up and my fiancé sat with the other people who were rejected entry and it was good although a lot was blocked off.

Wait to the surprise at the end. The back of the temple was so unique it made the visit there extremely special. Walking it and then through the back getting to the terrace of elephants was truly unique and also quiet. I guess not many people do that so that in itself makes it worth it.
Whole day temple visit. The temple is nice if you're following the whole map of Central Angkor Thom. hut of course if you wi compare this to Angkor Wat and Ta Phrom, it's smaller

Just beautiful! One of our favorites.. We saw a number of females being denied access to Baphuon Temple because of the way they were dressed. It doesn't matter how many thousands of miles you flew to get here. The dress code is strictly enforced: Female shoulders and knees should be covered. Bringing shawls does not help. The guards' reasoning is clear: there are so many steps to climb, and if you're not decently dressed, you would be exposing body parts unintentionally and unnecessarily. After all, it's a temple which accords respect.
Tall and impressive . This is a very tall temple that reminds me of a pyramid, young children are not allowed to climb it and you will also need to wear long pants due to their religious beliefs.

Keep in mind that children under 8-10 are not allowed to climb!. We were early in the morning there, but we missed some time while waiting at Bakan's queue, (approx 30 minutes) so we decided not climbing to the top. Obviously it is worth trying, but you can always skip it! This temple is very close to the Elephants' terrace and you can still walk it on the ground easily. Keep in mind that children under 8-10 are not allowed to climb!

Unique and impressively large. The elevated walkway was just the start of unique details with this temple.It is impressive in it scale and also very steep. They did not allow my 5 and 7 year old to climb which frankly I was grateful for as it really was very steep and once you got up the top, not roped off or secure and very easy to take a tumble off.Great views of the complex from the top and also some impressive carvings.At he back, they have taken some bricks from the original temple and tried to construct t a reclining Buddha. It kind of bulges out from the building!

Can't take children under 12. We were disappointed when they turned us away with our 8 year old child. They said it was too steep, but we had climbed many others the day before that were treacherous with no problem.

Awe Inspiring. A fantastic pyramid like temple, looks huge close up. It is part of Angkor Thom and very near Terrace of Elephants and other sites. The only downside is that they do not allow children under 12-13 to climb up the temple, so our 8 year old could not go up.

Beautiful Temple, pity our 11 year old could not enter.. Unfortunately, I had to wait outside with my 11 year old while my husband and 13 year old daughter visited. I think age restrictions need to be reviewed. I understand there are some steep parts, as there are at Angkor Tho, which my son was able to climb. I am sure an 11 year old could manage the step stairs much better then some of the 60+ tourists we say around the temples attempting to climb the steep steps.

Great temple - reclining buddha at the back. This temple is in the Angkor Thom complex and is one of many! You can climb to the top (if you don't get sunstroke first) and the views are lovely. Steep steps. There is a reclining Buddha at the back of the temple that you could easily miss, but once you keep looking at it, it will take shape eventually. There is a lovely long walkway to get to the temple and if you've got time, definitely worth a visit.

Gorgeous views! . The view on the bridge to the temple helps you to realize just how large it is. This has many steps, so certainly recommended for someone that is good condition. At the top there is a slight breeze which makes the sweat worth it, alongside the view!

Respect Dress Code When Visiting Temples. I like the drama of the long walk on the bridge heading to the main temple. I got few good shots from the far view alone.Tip: be prepared to climb. The main structure is like a huge building of staircases, all going to the center top. The solid proportion and angular structure makes the site pleasing and easy for photography, if you into it.

Good to see but steep steps, not for the faint hearted . Enjoyed our walk round the temple and climbing to the highest allowable point. But stairs were steep and got a little crowded at points. Buddha was interesting to see.

Climb as high as you get !. At start pretty basic temple with (yet again) amazing story. Highly recomend to climb as high up as they allow, really nice to see the temple area from a different angle. The stairs are steep!!
Nice temple. Nice temple and depending the stage of your visit, it may end up being a case of too many temples. Still worth a visit.
My favourite!!. Of all the temples, this was my fabourite. The most beautiful, tallest and atmopheric temple there is.
Again visited as part of the mini tour. Visited as part of the mi ni tour and was as magnificent as the rest of the temples. Get a Tuk Tuk to make it easier to visit and you wont be disappointed.
Beautiful and great walk between waters. Magnificent, worth a visit. Make sure to include in your list of priorities of Angkor Wat visits. Great walk between waters.

One of the oldest temples. Located on the west side of Angkor Thom, the Baphuon is one of the oldest temples in the city that existed before the Angkor Thom itself. Climbing up to the top of Baphuon offers visitors great view of the surroundings.

Many stairs. We visited many temples during our stay and this temple is one of those temples with a lot of stairs. So, if you're planning to visit this, make sure you have enough water with you and wear enough coverage to protect you from sunburn!

Part of Angkor Tom Complex. Take your time to walk through this complex of at least 3 main structures and ancient palace grounds. Very interesting. Make note of the "Sleeping Buddha" on the back side of the main structure - it may be a bit obscure but it is indeed visible in the constructions lines of the building - pretty neat!!

Surprise at the back. The temple is less appealing compared to it's famous neighbor, Bayon, but is nonetheless an interesting site to visit, mostly due to the story behind its restoration. Coined as the world's largest jigsaw puzzle, Baphuon was once torn apart & put together piece by piece. The reclining Buddha at the back wall of the temple was another interesting thing to see, though one has to use some imagination to visualize it.Just be sure to dress appropriately when visiting the place cos I saw other tourists denied entry due to their sleeveless tops & shorts. Mines was long enough to cover half my knees & was allowed to enter.
Beautiful temple, worth the visit. This temple is a big temple of Ankor. It's beautiful, not so much details as other temples but very beautiful and nice to see.

Ready to climb. Baphuon is recently opened and there are less tourist but the temple is fanscinating. This is the only mountain temple in Angkor Thom. Need stamina to climb on a hot weather but you it worth it when you reach the top.

Obligatory visit because it is adjacent to Bayon. This temple is not as beautiful as Bayon however it is much older and since it is right beside Bayon you may as well walk the 300 meters and go give it a half hour walkabout. When you exit this temple make sure you walk behind Bayon so you can take the water photos. You may also find ripe starfruit on the trees outside Baphuon which tastes great on a hot day.

Less tourists makes it more spectacular. A stunning long stone walkway leads to this temple, where you can climb to the top on a very steep, near ladder like set of steps. The view is incredible from the top, as is walking along the corridors inside. Lots of random placed stones lay on the grounds which apparently were ready for restoration works until the time of the Khmer Rouge. Maybe one day they'll get back to it, although sometimes it's nice to see it in the state it is, safety hazards and all.

Hidden find . Our 7th temple and the sun was hot! Bring lots of water and suncream. We enjoyed this temple with it's long walkway path and steep climb up into the small temple. We enjoyed our visit by tuk tuk and a guide book no noisy tour groups. Be prepared for fake guides that charge you, sellers calling you to buy things and book sellers. But that's at every popular attraction. Please don't give money to the children they are working for someone the money won't go to them and they will go out and do the same thing the next day. Remember to promote good tourism in the country.

Siem Reap Adventure. first temple that I actually noticed the security guards enforcing the dress code law. So why only this temple and not the rest as well? Is it just because this was the royal palace temple? I quite enjoyed the climb and view from the top. Good to know that they are restoring this temple.

Buddhist temple inside Angkor Thom. Baphuon was one of the amazing temples inside Angkor Thom. There was a long stone bridge built over the sandy surface which led to the main entrance of the temple. Climbing up the stairs you could walk round the temple along the corridor on the first level. You could go to the top by climbing up a very steep staircase to have a better view. It was a Buddhist temple and a 9 meter x 70 meter statue of a reclining Buddha was built on the external wall at the western side of the second level but you need some imagination to admire the statue as the features of Buddha were not so prominent.
Still being retired, very elegant. This huge temple is still being restored. We saw 4-5 Buddhist monks dressed in orange going in and out and along the long causeway. Impressive site.
Life time experience. A lifetime experience to watch, climb and walk around. If you love hiking this is the place for you but beware of risk of falling down and breaking bones.

One of the big temples. Located next to the Elephant Terrace and the main stopping point for a lot of tour buses, this temple can get very crowded and it being the halfway point of many temple tours, most people would've visited this temple during the heat-intense noon period. It can get pretty exhausting. A three-tiered temple that allows visitors to climb all the way to the top, this temple is another well-preserved monument that has lots of details intact.

Amazing place. One of main temples to visit n the area, for me the architecture was amongst the best of them all. Definitely organise a guide there is so much to understand about the different temples and the history
Enchanting!!. This is one of the really big temples of the Angkor Wat Empire. Another winner! If you will check the other side of it from afar, you will actually see a leaning Buddha. Try it.

Central of Angkor Thom. Baphuon is the central temple of Angkor Thom. We climbed up the temple and enjoy another different view across the park. Please note that you need to cover your knees and shoulder in order to enter Baphuon.

Well Worth the Trip. The Baphuon is a little off the road, but it should be visited in conjunction with Angkor the Bayon in Angkor Thom. Far fewer peolpe were at this temple, and it was not as completely restored as the Bayon or Angkor Wat.
Good place to visit. I love this temple .. Outside Angkor Thom is the Terrace of the Elephants and next is BAphuon temple .less tourist nice architecture and great view ..

Underrated.....Better than Bayon. Yeah yeah yeah Bayon's got all those faces, but doesn't match up to Baphuon and it's towering pinnacle. If you can make it all the way to the top (there's some pretty imposing steps), you'll get the best views outside of Angkor Wat. The cleared field and long walkway are amazing. It seems less visited than the others but it's definitely was #2 outside of Angkor Wat.

Nice view on top!. It is worth the climbs of steps. Be careful though. Not suitable for the elderly. Visit this temple after your visit to Bayon; and proceed to the Terrace of the Elephants after this.

One of my favorites despite the steepness of stairs. This is one of my favorites because of the majestic nature of this temple. We climbed steep stairs just to explore it and so worth the view from above. Fortunately, they built wooden stairs with barristers so it was easier and safer to climb vs the other temples. Don't forget to see the reclining Buddha as you exit the temple.As with all the other temples in Siem Reap, this has undergone restoration after being ravaged by war. This temple is still beautiful to see - pictures do not do it justice. Hearing from the tour guide on what it looked like as it was originally built makes you think and imagine what could have been.

Great Views. Scary climb up some very steep stair to the top where the views were quite amazing. This is a nice temple but the real attraction in in the terraces nearby with the elephant terrace and the terrace of the leper king having amazing carvings

Worth a wander. More ancient ruins, with the amazing carvings & sculptures you see at most of them. Have a slow look around & enjoy. Locals selling things at the entrance & can be very in your face, but try to remember that this is their livelihood & they dont realize how annoying this is, so try to be patient :-)

Baphuon Temple. Near to Bayon. Less tourist compare to bayon. The temple mountain still stands. But most of the structure already ruin. The stairs to the pyramid top is very steep and there is nothing much to see up there.
Picturesque. Very nice place less crowded and quite panaromic views from the temple..Tip:Take water and umbrella this place can get very hot and humid during day..

My favorite temple to climb at Angkor. Of all the temples we climbed at Angkor, and we did quite a few in one day, Baphuon seemed to be the one where everyone was having a good time. There is something particularly enjoyable here: the jungle views, the steepness, the thrill, location, etc. Watch your head as you climb through several stone doorways, arches, etc. I was wearing a cap with a button on top, and that helped me as I did hit the top of my head once. Enjoy the climb up and down, just take your time.
Scenic view from above.. Climbing up the top storey and sweating, I found it another good place to see around. But one do need quite a lot energy.

Largest jigsaw ever!. Be prepared to climb. Incredibly steep staircases, almost ladders - you need to be relatively fit to get to the top. The final top piece is still not open to the public.It is the world's largest jigsaw puzzle ever after the Cambodian war that caused untold damage.Keep an eye out for the Reclining Buddha at the end of the tour, 60 metres long and reinstated a few years ago.
Another amazing site. It's hard to stay focused when visiting Angkor as getting templed out is a real danger. Spread the highlights out. This is a highlight.
The climb is worth it but watch your step - the treads are very narrow!. A long causeway leads to a central complex with three long steep climbs to the centre. Not for those with vertigo!

Less touristy but as majestic as Angkor Wat. For me, this temple is as majestic as Angkor Wat so I was quite surprised that it did not receive as many tourists as Angkor Wat. It was a blessing anyway because I can appreciate more about this temple and enjoy our visit here. It is located just a short distance after Bayon Temple, on your left hand side. You can climb to the top of the temple which gives you a very nice view. Please be careful because the stairs are very steep and climbing down would be very challenging. Make sure you use a proper shoes with good traction for your safety.We went there unprepared and without a guide so we missed the reclining Buddha. So make sure you dont miss it. Based on previous reviews, the reclining Buddha is located on the west side.

Magnificent Ancient Temple. A long walk towards this temple and get ready yourself with a good pair of shoes..I totally felt in love with this temple and there is a section of the temple whereby you need to climb up and great view on top of it..It is a very quiet temple and during my visit, there was not much of a crowd here which I totally love its serenity and totally amazed at this ancient building itself...I would recommend anyone who wants to visit here to spend about 3 to 4 hours and do not forget to bring lots of drinking water as it really hot out here..

Worth a visit. Baphuon seems to be a less known destination for the masses. But I would recommend it. Both because it has less tourists but also because it has its beauty in its own right.You can climb almost to the very top of this temple giving you a fantastic view over the area. On your way down don't miss the reclining Buddha on the west side.
Nice temple. Nice temple to have a look at on the way from Bayon to the terrace of the Elephants. It was closed when we visited but had a look around the outside
Angkor. Great temple around Angkor Wat.You will get to see a few along the way and it was a nice drive with great greenery scenery.

Amazing temple and not as busy as others. It was good to wonder around in this place, not that many people took the time to go there, so that makes it good to chill around, take the time for photos, rest relax. There is a big climb to the top, and in the back of it there is a reclining Buddha in the bricks (which is in ruins).

Don't miss this one out.. A better temple to visit that some of the other more-frequented temples by most tourists. It's more impressive than some and far quieter - we got shots with NO-ONE IN THEM. Try that at Angkor Wat.

Worth the climb!. This temple was an accidental detour as our tuktuk had a flattie on the way to the elephant terrace. But what a lucky accident it was.
This was the tallest temple we visited (3 stories) with some very steep stairs to climb.
Similar architecture to the Bayon temple and worth a visit if you go to the elephant terrace.

A wonder. An amazing view with a 3D reclining Buddha on the wall.
I had a beautiful view from the top!
I was so happy to come here!

You can't go to Siem Reap without doing the temples. After you have been around, most of the temples they begin to merge into one, but if you look closely you can see they are built differently. They are so interesting you can't go to Siem Reap without trying to do all of them.
Another temple to enjoy. Make sure you view this temple too. A very spiritual place, but well worth the look. Take the time to stay in Siem Reap to see all the temples you can.

Lots of stairs but it gave you a goof view from the top. It has lots of stairs. I climbed up to the very top and very satisfied tih the view from the top.
The journey back downstairs was damn scary. The stairs was very sloping. You need to be careful not to fall down.

Great view of the area from the top of the complex. This was an interesting temple to explore. If you climb to the top, you get a great view of the area. The only downside are the guys who follow you around trying to show you photo opps for tips. I spent about an hour here.

Worth the visit. This is a great place to go visit a buddhist temple. This temple takes at least 1 hour of your time. Make sure you are wearing proper clothes. Take picture on top, its a worth the effort to get there. In the back of the temple there is a sleeping buddha embedded in the rocks. Follow the path for the visit after wards

A boy suprised me. The location is easy to find, but also easy to miss it.I was passed by and miss this place when I first get to the temple. When you visit the small tour for a whole day, you will find this temple is just similar to the others. So, not really a big surprise when you visit this. I have a bad experience over there. I was guided by a "volunteer student" that he shows me all around the place and explain some history for me.However, he was asking me for donation at last.Well, it is fine if you raise out this at the very beginning.I really feel not very comfortable after he showed me the way and a little bit pushy on the donation amount. Finally I just give a very small amount and he asked for tips for himself. I was quite surprise about what he did.Remember to wear sleeves clothes and long pants on the date you visit. Many place had dress code for visiting the temple. You may buy some traditional goods outside the attractons and all the pants. Long pants is quite good for visitng Angkor Wat as the weater is far too hot and sweat a lot.

Baphuon worth the walk.. Baphuon is a smaller temple but still worth visiting. It is a bit less than a kilometre north from Bayon temple in the Angkor Thom complex. There is a nice walk into the temple along a terrace between two ponds - great for photos.

Hidden Gem - tucked away in the woods, don't miss it.. This temple is tucked away in the woods so could easily be missed. You have walk down a long bridge like path way to reach this temple which adds to the beauty of the temple. It's a magnificent temple with a small pyramid at the top. Not as busy as the other temples, very quiet and calm feel to this temple. The steps are not for the faint hearted or anyone with walking difficulties. They are extremely steep but so worth climbing to experience the view from the top. Take your time going up and down these steps, you don't want to be falling down these steps - trust me! Some tourists were even over taking other people on these stairs - not a good move could easily cause an accident as well as making other people feel even more nervous about their decent as these people over take them.Beautiful pictures from the top of this temple. Do remember ladies you will need to cover your shoulders and wear appropriate length shorts - nothing too short! I used a scarf that I'd bought to cover my shoulders whilst in this site as it was too hot to be wearing a sleeved top. Their are guards at the entrance to the temple that will turn you away if you're not dressed appropriately.
Part of Angkor Thom Mini Tour. As part of the Angkor Thom Mini Tour, Baphuon Temple was hidden inside the forest covered with trees. Very big temple with a small pyramid on top.
beautiful. it's beautiful, not many people, calm, serene and i like it more than bayon which is just nearby....

Baphuon is a wonderful temple in Angkor Thom. Baphuon is in the Angkor Thom area situated in serene surroundings that allow you to appreciate the beauty of the building and consider it's history and that is was restored so we can enjoy & learn. The giant reclining Buddha on an outer wall is remarkable and the views from the top are wonderful
Great temple. Beautiful temple set a part of the other temple compound, the temple was ruin but you will be amazed with the structure and architect. Worth to pay a visit

The Baphuon, another older temple to see. The Baphuon, another older temple to seeI appreciated the alley of stones, slightly covered walkway caratère as found in other civilizations (see the pictures).
Magnificent.. Climb to the top. Its worth it. One of my favourite temple in Angkor. Remember to wear long skirt and cover your shoulder for woman.

Beautiful. I felt this was one of the most beautiful. The big walk in "bridge" makes for a sight. Felt it was huge and awe inspiring. Too bad it was closed at the time we went by. I am pretty sure it opens because there were stairs and visit guidelines but we oursleves didn´t get to climb up top. Seems to be in pretty good shape compared to some of the others. This is a mandatory passage when you follow the Angkor Thom visit guidelines just after Bayon, so you will certainly have a look here if your ever come visit, so don´t bother making time in your schedule just for it.

Shiva Temple. This amazing three tiered Temple is dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva. This temple took 51 years to restore and was only opened in 2011. There are a lot of steps so make sure you wear good shoes and some water. But the views are marvelous. If your not so ambitious then take a stroll along the Walkway.

Impressive temple. The temple is very impressive and unique. The views from the top of the temple is stunning as well. However, do keep in mind the stairs are very narrow and amazingly steep. Many tourist were afraid to get down but they probably did in the end! All in all, don't skip this temple. Simply stunning indeed.

Beautiful Temple - Even if you are Heights Challenged!. This was the first temple I visited in the Angkor Thom complex. It is beautiful, and at the very top--if you have the stomach--you can get a lay of the Land of Thom! Particularly beautiful is the West end of the Baphuon. During the 1960's to the 1970's, the entire Baphuon was taken apart stone by stone, and lay in a rubble when war broke out. I don't think the re-assembling began until after the war. It's quite beautiful. General Recommendation for Wat-seeing - go early in the morning or late in the afternoon--avoid the heat of the day.

Pyramid Temple. A stone causeway connected the three tired temple. It was built in mid 11 th century by Udayadityabarman II . It was dedicated to Lord Shiva later it was transformed into Buddhist temple. To visit upper tiers one need to use steep wooden stairs . A word of caution those who are not physically fit should not try to climb up specially senior people . It is suggested to avoid tight pant and shoe with heel which will be hazardous for stair climbing .At the top tier there is tower . From distance the temple look so beautiful and from the top also the surrounding is eye soothing.

very impressive. Walking up to this temple (near bayon) that I had never even read about, I was stunned. it is almost as impressive as Bayon & Angkor Wat themselves. It is a very high, with very steep stairs, but the view from the top (and the cool breeze) is worth it. The entrance way from the front is beautifully picturesque and a great place to stop for a rest after exploring bayon. You of course have to have knees and shoulders covered here as it is a temple.

Temple dedicated to Hindu God Shiva. This temple was built in mid 11th century. The temple was dedicated to Hindu God Shiva. The architecture is fine. View from the top is very good but with a tough climb.
Staggering temple. Watch the mossies but a fantastic temple. Be warned there are many steep wooden steps here. Apparently the original stone steps are too steep & too high!

World's largest jigsaw . Part of the Angkor Thom complex , the royal palace has a very different feel to Angkor Watt , a very steep pyramid type structure , not many people there , part of the walk from Bayon to Leaper King Terrace , worth the climb

Baphuon Temple is large but easily overlooked. Being situated between the Bayon and the Elephant Terrace, the fairly large Baphuon temple can't really not be noticed but nevertheless it is easy to overlook. Fortunately for a repeat visitor like myself, it can be explored a little bit at a time. The long elevated walkway is actually quite spectacular and during the many years of reconstruction it was the only part many visitors ever saw. On my last visit I rode my bicycle around the outside of the massive structure and explored the outer perimeters, that may not sound very exciting, but it is something I always like to do after getting to know the main structures of any Angkor temple.

Off the beaten path temple, set back in the woods and no crowds. Go during dusk for best pictures. Even though this is not a "famous" temple within the complex it is still a nice temple with timeless history. Be sure to stop here for zero crowd picture. It is on the way out of the bigger complex.

Amazing. Also known as the royal palace. Build different yet again and an amazing experience after the Bayon temple. On the long pathway you can take perfect photos and from the top you have an amazing view!!\Worth a visit and in my eyes a must in Siem Reap!!

Look Out For The Huge Reclining Buddha at The Back of Temple. The long walkway towards the temple is quite impressive. Inside, it requires a lot of climbing of stairs. What's most special about this temple is the huge reclining Buddha at the back of the temple. As you are leaving the temple following the guided path, stop while you are at the back of temple. You can see a gigantic reclining Buddha on the temple - there is a small signage that points this out.

Worth a visit . Great to walk up stairs and see the view of the surrounding area, bit of a steep climb but worth it so be careful with climb and decent.Of all the temples I visited this was the one with less people so you can get a good experience, but for me I like others more so if you have time constraints and can't visit all I would cut this one.

"World's biggest jigsaw". This temple is completely underrated and not recommended enough. This was likely one of the best experiences within Angkor, in my opinion.There were so few people there, which was great!! (2pm on a monday)There are 3 levels which you can transcend - tough climbing but worth it. It's hilarious to walk around and wondr what it was supposed to look like had the original instructions on how to put it all (300,000 stones) back together. What an adventure! !!!

What a view, what a temple.. I've visited this temple a couple of times over the decaded while it was still under restauration. This year was the first time I climbed all the way to the top of the fully restaured temple. The climb on the modern wooden stars is steep, very steep. Going up is not easy and sweaty. Climbing down is all out dangerous, keep your hands to the rail and move slowly. But it is worth the efford. The temple is beautiful. Pity we couldn't climb to the highest point.
Great view. The view afforded from the top of this temple was excellent, buts do be careful on the way up, as them stairs are lethal!!!

Dedicated to Lord Shiva. Baphuon Temple is very near to Bayon. you can access by walking distance. The design of this temple is unique and it's believed that those days King will have their prayers in this temple. So its considered as one of the powerful place in angkor. After visiting Baphuon temple, you can walk around the other side of the temple to visit elephant tarrace and lapper king tarrace.

A tad underwhelming. Given the magnificence of some of the other temples (particularly Bayon), I found Baphuon underwhelming - particularly given the energy sapping climbing. At times it felt like a chore and I was expecting much more after the draining scale to the top.Maybe it would be an idea to explore this temple before Bayon.
Amazing landscape. It was resurrected recently and opened to public as recent as two years back. You must go on top of the temple to witness beautiful landscape of the temple complex.

One of my favorites of the Temples of Angkor. Located close to Bayon this temple is a lot of fun. You can explore both in one day easily. Views from the top are great although accessibility is by very steep stairs both up and down. The condition of the remaining temple is pretty good since it was restored. You will be greeted by the monkeys at the beginning of the walkway.

The detail is incredible.. I read up on Ankor before I came but there is so much here and each temple is so similar yet different. The amount of detail is what blew me away and in Baphuon Temple, the beautiful pools. There were steps to ascend to the very top where, no doubt, the view is spectacular. Unfortunately I would have been stuck up there forever so I didn't go up. (pout) Also, Ladies need to cover their shoulders to access some of these places so its a good idea to wear a t-shirt, not a tank top, it's so ease to get sunburned out here too so T-shirt is just a really good idea all round.
Climb up and enjoy the nature around it. One of the best temples of Angkor Thom, not suitable for old folks or kinds though. You have to climb some wood stairs and they are a little scary.

The Temple of the Sleeping Buddha. He's not hard to spot, but the tragic thing about Baphuon, a mid-eleventh-century temple, was to be restored after French excavations. All the stones were laid out and meticulous records kept, but subsequently burnt by the Khmer rouge. Today a large portion of the stones still lie sitting in the jungle beside the temple. No one has the foggiest idea of how to put the shrine back together again now. Tragic.

Angkor Thom. As recommended in other posts, I'd suggest getting a map of the Angkor Thom complex before visiting. Make sure you check out Baphuon, learning its history. It's a large area and right near the king's giant pool and the queen's smaller one. Definitely worth a look, especially if you have a book/ info on what they assume it originally looked like!

Do the climb, and enjoy the view on top. This is another beautiful temple within the Angkor Thom. And worth the trip. This temple is known as the stairway to heaven, with the rainbow bridge, according to the tour guide. We walked the narrow bridge which lead to the temple, and then began to climb slowly up the 3 levels. The climb is steep, and we had to be really careful.When we reached the top, we felt that the climb was totally worth the effort - the view was gorgeous, and it was also windy. That was a good break from the dry heat. We stayed up there for a while to enjoy the place. The climb down was a little more overwhelming, but we managed to get down with lots of caution taken. Love the Baphuon!

It's tiring, but worth it!. It's a pretty high climb up insanely steep stairs, but it's definitely worth it, especially since the view from above was gorgeous!Getting to climb this landmark was memorable, and I loved looking for the face of the supposed Reclining Buddha by the back.By the way, you've to cover your shoulders and knees for this temple! :)
Another temple worth visiting. The Baphuon temple is worth visiting. It's a big area and has a nice view over that area. Also a lot of stairs.

Find the reclining Buddha!. Up to the top for a superb view! Really, one of the best temples in the Angkor Thom complex. Again, built on several levels, you'll climb many stairs, but it's worth it.Then go to the side with the reclining Buddha. It took us a while to figure this out, but once you make it out, it becomes as plain as day, to state the obvious! It is incredibly well done, and bear in mind this goes back a thousand years.From here you can move on to the Terraces of the Elephants and the Leper King. Definitely well worthwhile to visit Baphuon.We had a tour guide, and this certainly helped us.

Royal!!. I loved this temple amongst other temples. It is very royal and it has a wonderful entrance and bridge. Don't miss it. Clime to the top and take pictures to the land under, it gives you a real royal feeling.

No go for vertigo! . Passed by and got lost in the gardens on our way to Bayon, the surrounds are beautiful just watch out for the biting ants! Steps were very steep to get up to the top, and normal temple rules apply, although some visitors thought they could get in in a vest top and shorts! Views are amazing and there's a shady spot to rest after your descent.

steep stairs, nice view. This is a 3-tier pyramid structure that you need to climb two sets of steep staircaes to the top. The interior corridors and walls are magnificent. Sadly, I cannot locate the outline of the sleeping Buddha from the back side of the temple. Two reminders: 1) no tank tops for visiting this temple; 2) beware of the teens hiding inside the temple, giving you info of the temple and asking for tip afterwards.

Lots of climbing. This temple is a tough steep climb but it is worth it, the view from the top is very nice indeed. It is joined to the elephant terrace by a long walkway which I thought was very cool. If you visit in the early afternoon there really aren't too many crowds but take care on the stairs. Definitely one of the temples I would recommend in the park.

Impressive but smaller. Smaller temple than the more famous areas. Dont just visit what the guides and taxis recommend. Good condition and better than some of the other temples. Very much a sun trap though.

Why do most temples have to be tall? Are they sun worshippers?. I walked from Bayon temple to get there. This temple looked different as well. It has a unique design. It is a 3-tiered temple mountain built as a state temple. Here I needed to catch some breath since you need to climb the steep stairway to get to the top. The view on top of the temple was great but it was still hot. Not that I complained a lot of the weather being too sunny that day.

Three tiered temple. Baphuon temple is located in Angkor Thom, northwest of Bayon. It was built in mid 11th century. It is a three-tiered temple mountain built as the state temple of Udayadityavarman II. It was dedicated to Hindu God Shiva. Its architecture is fine. View from the top is very good but the climb is bit tough.
Picturesque, but the climb is tough.. I would have loved to see the view from the top of the temple, but even my physically fit daughter found the steep stairs and the crowds a challenge.

Temple of the reclining Buddha. The Baphuon is one of the temples inside the Angkor Thom city. It is a pyramid style temple under reconstruction. It is possible to climb all the way to the top. On the west face a large reclining Buddha can be found, it has been part of the reconstruction. Good to visit as part of a visit to Angkor Thom. Of course the Bayon temple is the real centerpiece of Angkor Thom.

Other temples are more impressive. I didn't find this temple quite as impressive. It is steep if you walk up and the carvings aren't in quite as good condition as others elsewhere in the park. Not a 'must see' but OK if you are visiting Angkor Thom to have a quick look.

Kids under 12 not allowed to climb up. Wish I had seen this mentioned before. Other than that, another awesome set of ancient bricks. Unique feature is the raised walk way up to the temple. And then you (if you are over 12) can climb some rather steep stairs all the way up ... once you get back down and circle to the back, you can make out, very faintly, the outlines of a very large sleeping Buddha.

Dedicated to Lord Shiva!. Bapuhuon temple is located inside Angkor Thom. It is three tired mountain temple, and it was the State temple of King Udayadityavarman. This temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva, and it stands 34-35 meters tall. Later in 15 th century, this has been converted to Buddhist temple. A huge reclining Buddha can be found on the upper level. It is very dull and dim, and if you look at it very alertly only, your eyes can find it. This temple was built of sand stone, and due to its huge, immense size, this has been unstable in the years to come. Large portions are already in ruins. It's architectural style is Khmer. Our group consisted of 6 people, and a private tour had been arranged. The Angkor Tour Guide Service took care of us so well. Mr. Sok Chea, who beautifully took us to all the places in his nicely air conditioned van, stayed with us throughout the day, always with a smiling face, always willing to be helpful. He is such a wonderful person, and I would recommend his name to anyone who is thinking of planning a trip to Cambodia.

Between Bayon & Terrace of Elephants. We visited Bayon first and came here before the Terrace of Elephants, and really enjoyed this part.It's setback back a little but visible from the road, which makes for some great views.The walk up it is nice but the steps are pretty steep, although newly built and with a rail.It's impressive at the top but unfortunately the very top is closed off, so you'll have to settle for the views two-thirds of the way up.Well worth it!

Nice view on top. Beautiful temple and the entrance walkway of the temple is very impressive. To get on the top of the temple, you must climb many stairs but it worth to climb. The view from the top of the temple is so nice.

steep climb. The Baphuon is close to the Bayon. It's steep and tricky to climb and the carvings aren't so well-preserved. There's a long causeway leading to it . On the North side, the upper terrace is in the form of a sleeping Buddha; it's quite hard to make out; see if you can spot it!

Mostly overlooked. We found this temple on our 2nd temple visit day. This temple is not much advertised not sure why but it has become my favourite temple. It is well maintained, from the top you have got a great view, not too many carvings, clear design, sleeping Buddha on the back of the temple, nice forest walk around just a good atmospheric place where you can rest with a lesser crowd of visitors at the top and enjoy some moments for yourself.

Few tourists. We visited after Bayon and walked along a impressive walkway up to the entrance of the temple. Worth it just for the walkway with great views from the top. We were surprised how few tourists were here.

Impressive access. Definitely below Angkor Wart and Bayon. But the paved access is "royal" and you can appreciate it from the top of the temple. The temple itself is OK. It can be visited after the Bayon, next door. Good to know you need to have long trousers to access. Best time for photos would be early afternoon. Toilets are around 10 min walk away.
IN RUINS -worth visiting. on the way to famous TAPROHM Temple we can just stop for a while to see this Baphuhon temple which is in ruins.WORTH PRESERVING FOR FUTURE GENERTION.

Highly recommended temple. such a beautiful restored temple complex, we were on our own so we explored the cr*p out of it! loved every section and area and the walkway was just amazing, we walked around the back, dont forget to do that, there are many beautiful huge trees worth seeing here

My favourite temple, by far. Rented a bicycle and was riding along the cluster of temples near Bayon (though without a map - totally impromptu and highly recommended if you're into relaxing/exploring) and wandered here by chance (the elevated walkway surrounded by a lake attracted me). Turned out to be my favourite. The stairs up are tough (lots of them and seems to deter some), but the view from the top is very rewarding. Too bad the topmost section is closed off but from the highest platform it does look like a "Stairway to Heaven". I rested there for about 30 minutes under one of the 'windows'/arches and it was very, very relaxing with occasional wind breeze and view over the lake.

Beautiful. In my personal opinion this is the most beautiful structure in the Angkor complex. Sadly what we see is just a shadow of the original. Sign boards that explain recent restoration work give an idea of what the original looked like. For example the pinnacle tower had totally collapsed without a trace but must have appeared dazzling.

Inside the Angkor Thom complex!. This temple inside the Angkor Thom complex is interesting, because the temple was original built as a Hindu temple & then was converted to a Buddhist temple in 15th century.
