You can actually see where the stone workers have changed the carvings to reflect the change in religion.

Very amazing.. but annoyed by the minor tourist guide there... Very amazing building. The restoration information board needs to repair as the document displayed quite torn down. There are minor tourist guides stationed there looking for targets to offer rough commentary and request tips in return, quite annoyed by their aggressiveness. Quite steep to climb all the way up but cant go to top as its been blocked. Feel like getting closer to the heaven..

Historic temple. Located in the Angkor Thom complex, it was originally erected as a Hindu temple in mid-11th century by Udayadityavarman II, later converted to a Buddhist temple in the 15th century. Recently restored with the aid of French archaelogists.

Causeway, climb, concealed.... Another of the amazing temples to see in the area. This one has a particularly striking causeway leading up to it, and some very steep stairs to climbs to reach the summit.
Around the back, there is a slightly hidden, not quite all there, huge reclining Buddha built into the second level.

Peaceful and picturesque place in Angkor Area. My favorite next to Angkor Wat. The peak of the temple is amazing. Although all temples look the same, Baphuon kinda gave me the relaxing vibe among all other temples. The smiling Buddha behind the temple, which was restored, gives your eyes a refreshing feel after going through a sea of temples in Angkor. Make sure you dont wear tank tops! :)

Restored and revealing. Baphuon is not as famous as the Bayon or Angkor Wat but it is as special. The restoration work going on here is trying to bring back the exactness of the architecture. It's worth a visit just for observing archaeological conservation and its importance in action.
Good restoration project. This is my second time and Siem Reap, so glad I was able to go around Baphuon Temple. Our guide gave us an insight on how it was restored by a French team.
Intricate. This temple as all temples are unique. Outstanding is the reclining Buddha, makes rocket science out of Lego. Intriguing, just as all the temples are.

Gem of a temple, tucked away. We were heading to the elephant terrace when we found Baphuon. They are right next to each other, yet all of the hordes or tourists were passing by this temple. Their loss was our gain! This is a hidden gem in the Angkor temples. We had a phenomenal time exploring it. The walkway is held up by hundreds of pillars. It is beautiful. There are lakes surrounding it and forestry behind it. There is even a path that leads you around the back to the elephant terrace. Highly recommend adding this to your list of temples to see!

An Example OF Restoration Challenges. A short walk from the Bayon temple, Baphuon Temple is a clear example of the challenge in restoring these ancient structures. Approaching the temple, the ground is covered with numbered stones the location of which are now unknown as the restoration has been progress for more than fifty years. Though it may appear daunting, climb the two levels to the top - great views, but some may find the steepness of the stairs unsettling.

Interesting temple. After visiting Angkor Wat and Ta Prohm, you kinda feel tired of visiting other temples.I nearly missed this temple as it was recommended by my tuktuk driver. But gladly I did go there and climbed up the stairs. It was a stunning view up there.

Photographers Dream. Up the road a bit from Bayon Temple and next the Elephant Terraces, this temple is a great one for those tired from 'Angkor Wat walking'. This template has a compartively small footprint, however it does make up for it with the raised stone causeway and vertical scope.Make the effort to climb the steep staircases to the very top as the view is spectacular. However, when decending the stairs its best to adopt a sideways gait, focus on your feet, and don't look at the ground.

Giant puzzle. Hats off to human race for building such structure making us think with astonishment, "how did they do this 1000 years back".You might not find anything unusual about this place unless you really read the history of this temple, so please read before exploring and it will then reveal its secrets.Turn on: Well managed, proper signageTurn off: None

Baphuon Temple - Good Workout. The Baphuon Temple is a grand temple, a must see when you visit Angkor Thom. It is quite a workout to climb to the top of the temple and the view from the top is just magnificent. It is nice walk from the front gate of the temple, along a raised walkway, to the temple. There are a number of steep and narrow stairs you have to negotiate to get to the top. Well work a visit. Highly recommended.

Astonishing temple.. Wow this is great Baphuon Temple, located within the area of Angkor Thom, this beautiful temple presents itself perfectly preserved and adjacent to a fantastic natural pool, to reach this temple you must take the road that leads up to it just by walking near the large pool of water. Fantastic place but even more fantastic scenery for wonderful photographs.
Nice view from the top!. Stairs are steep, but very exciting and rewarding when you get to the top. A nice place for a rest after all the walking, and travelling from Angkor Wat and other temples.
Keep climbing to the top!. Very big temple in the middle of Lake. Very beautiful and do climb until the top and you will view the most amazing views around the temple. Tiring but worth every steps.

Great views!. This temple is a little set back from the main track. The elevated walkway out to the temple is pretty cool. Climb the stairs to the top, the views are worth it! I definitely recommend stopping here. It won't take long to see and it is definitely worth it.There are a lot of stairs to the top so if climbing is difficult for you, you may want to skip this part. Around the backside of the temple some of the stones have been rearranged to create a reclining Buddha. It is pretty cool to see and doesn't require a lot of stairs to see.

My favorite temple!. It's not that famous as compared to Angkor Wat and Bayon but among all the temples, I can say that this one is my favorite. The temple is a pyramid-like structure and seems symmetrical. Tourists can go up by level but the stairs are too steep! Going up will not be a problem but going down can be a challenge. My favorite pictures are also from this temple. Views from the top are very scenic as compared to the views of Angkor Wat. Let me know if you are able to spot the reclining Buddha. ;)

Awesome. I watched local kids swim butt naked in a pound next to the temple picking Lillie flowers then watching them make things with the flowers and they where only around 5/6 years old was very interesting to watch ! I also got some wicked photos of the temples as it was a good day ! try go on a sunny day not to clowdy as you get better photos! remember water !! also be aware there will be lots of locals trying to sell you thing like books and pants and magnets ect ect so beware you will get a bit harassed and mainly outside the temples u will
Picture perfect. Inside Angkor Thom & Very Beautiful. Quiet in the morning recommend walking up then. Unfortunately many tourists leave their rubbish at this temple which is disgraceful.

Climb all the way up!. We witnessed a lady being denied entry to this temple as her knees were not covered-up. Didn't notice this policy being strictly upheld in the other temples. This temple resembles a pyramid and the best part of it is at the top. The stairs at the sides are very steep and the elderly will definitely have problems...even we went slightly wobbly in the knees when looking down. We had a good rest while enjoying the view from above.

Reclining Buddha and good views. The temple has many great photo-ops. It starts at the long elevated walkway to ther entrance, then up top you can take nice pictures with the lotus flowers and the views and on the back is a huge reclining Buddha built in to the temple base. On the way from Bayon to the terraces.

Stairways to heaven. Once was covered by bronze this spectacular temple is located inside Angkhor Thom. Spectacular view on top of the majestic temple. But be prepared for a long and hard work of climbing stairs. Our guide loong a local boy, told us that most temples built with many levels and with steep steps is to allow us humans to understand that it is hard to enter heaven. Interesting concept. Do visit this temple and explore its surrounding.

One of my favourite temples!. You must have your shoulders and knees covered to enter this temple! I wandered through the grounds in my tank and shorts on my second day of temple sight-seeing, but I made sure to come back on my third day, properly dressed, just to see this temple...and I'm so glad I did! There were perhaps 5-7 other people in the whole place, so it was a wonderful photograph opportunity, and you really got to feel the ancient atmosphere around you as you perused the galleries and terraces. You can't go all the way up to the tippy top anymore, but you can still climb pretty high on skinny, steep steps.

Be prepared to climb. This temple was restored in 2011.There is a long walkway to the temple. During the wet season, there will be lotus and water lilies fronting the temple. Children below the age of 12 not allowed in and proper attire, that is covering of knees and shoulders, required here. Prepare to climb to the top for a great view of the surrounding area.

Worth the climb!. This temple is one of the most recently excavated temples, according to my guidebook. The temple has a long walkway from the entrance to the actual temple. Once you reach the temple, you have to climb steep stairways to reach the upper levels.The carvings are in good condition and the view from the top is excellent. It's worth the climb.

Beautiful temple, but hard to climb. CC ( 2014.07.26 ) This temple was beautiful like another Angkor remains, too. There was beautiful to see on the ground, and more beautiful on the top of the temple. It was to hard work to climb to steep slope, but was to worth to climb. On the top of the temple, view of looking down was very impressive and beautiful. Must go on the top, though it was dangerous.

Worth the Climb. This temple lies between the royal complex - Premeenaka and the Bayon. From the main road, you have to walk a couple of hundred metres on an elevated pathway to reach the base of the temple. The climb is steep so they don't allow kids below 12. Due to eh presence of Ta Prohm, Angkor Vat and Bayon, this temple often gets overlooked, so its comparatively less noisy and the views from the top are spectacular. There was originally a reclining Buddha on the top, however, not much remains now. Most people climb the temple for the views and the remains of the Buddha, thereby missing the hidden gems. On the 2nd level of the temple (it s a 3 level temple) there is a covered walkway on all sides, with stairs to the upper level on the north, east, west and south. The base of the stairways are covered with a chamber and on the outside walls of these chambers are brilliant bas reliefs depicting scenes from the Ramayana and Mahabharata - the two great Indian epics, not surprising since this was, originally a Shiva temple. You will miss these carvings if you walk through the walkway, you will have to get out on the platforms between the walkway and the base of the upper level to see these. The same ticket for the Angkor Archaeological Park is valid here.If you suffer from altophobia (fear of heights) or vertigo, please do not try to climb, its quite dizzy, especially while climbing down the stairs.

Hard to climb but absolutely worth it!. The Baphuon is located in Angkor Thom, northwest of the Bayon. Built in the mid-11th century, it is a three-tiered temple mountain, dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva. It is a nightmare to climb the steep stairs but the view and the walk in the corridors is absolutely worth it. Tip: Cover your shoulders and knees.

Steep Climb - Kids Aren't allowed. After walking through Bayon at Angkor Thom, this is probably the next "major" temple in the area. This temple mountain, is what it is...a man made mountain of sorts. Expect a power climb on really steep stairs. Vertigo will never be your friend especially after entering this temple. The tourism folks at the bottom of the temple (fronting the bridge) have a height requirement (I guess) in determining who gets to go in or not.Bas reliefs, APSARAs and the works may be found inside it, not to mention the amazing Khmer architecture.

No kids under 12 can climb. Like Angkor Wat and I am sure others, children under 12 and pregnant women are not allowed to climb up the temple. Disappointing and I am not sure why this rule exists. Frustrating when visiting with children (5 and 7) who are great climbers and I believe would have been safe… Certainly we have climbed many temples in other countries which are steeper/higher.

good temple. Baphuon temple it is best temple in siem reap .
it in side Bayon temple , it is far siem reap town about 8km.
it is very hinge , it have a lot caving on the wall.

Large and spectacular, but do not tarry unless you have lots of time. Famous for its now barely-recognisable, elevated 40 m sleeping Buddha on the west side - which it took me two visits to actually identify - Baphuan is one of the larger temples in the area. Much EFEO work continues, but I believe that there are more impressive temples for the newcomer to visit. The approach via the 200m sandstone walkway is certainly impressive, however. A worthwhile entree to the adjoining Royal Enclosure and Phimeanakas, I suggest.

Sky High. The main attraction of this place is basically how high up it is, so if you're not a person that's impressed by heights this might not be your kind of thing. This temple's structure is much simpler than the other temples in Angkor Thom but it makes up for that with its size. I was very impressed by how massive this temple looked and by the pillar-supported walkway at the entrance. The temple is really tall and you can climb up stairs to get all the way up to the top. Watch out for the steep steps though. The view at the top is fairly refreshing and you'd be quite surprised when you realize that you've gone up all those stairs! This visit was part of an itinerary planned out by our tuk tuk driver. It included Angkor Wat and most places in Angkor Thom. Walking around from temple to temple can get very exhausting (especially around noon) so I recommend resting adequately beforehand, using sunblock and drinking as much water as you can. And wear knee-covering pants when coming here; otherwise you might be denied access to certain temples.

For Women, Don't Wear Shorts. We went here on our own without a tour guide. We were not informed that wearing shorts for women is not allowed. And too bad I was wearing shorts because it was too hot in Siem Reap! So I was forced to buy local pants sold around Angkor Thom. This temple is pretty high. It's beautiful but prepare your legs for some huge climb. We went to Baphuon Temple before lunch (around 11am). There were a lot of people already. Perhaps you can visiting earlier.

The walk is nice, but you could probably skip it.. After visiting Bayon Temple, Baphuon is a bit of a let down. You might want to check it out first before exploring Bayon. Walk around the temple and take advantage of the tall trees and their shade. Checking out the grounds is more worth your time than checking out the ruins.

Outstanding Ancient Structure. Another great structure within the Angkor Thom area, don't forget to take the stairs all the way up, and head to the back of the complex as well to spot the sleeping Buddha!

Angkor - Baphuon Temple - Looked so much bigger from ground level. Moving from the Bayan Temple and heading towards the Terrace of Elephants you will find a superbly restored smaller temple called the Baphuon Temple which looks very large and impressive as you walk towards it through the various water storage lakes and along its raised walkway. Seemingly it is not a big as it seems, but it does stand out proud and would appear to be a fairly intact structure. The day we visited the gate was closed at the bottom of the steps leading up so we didn't venture to the top and possibly missed out on some great views if you read these other reports here on TA. However, for me it had a sense of grandeur in any event and the raised walkway leading to and from the temple added to this. The green coloured water surrounding it also added to the attraction. A great addition to the Angkor complex.

recently restored. Very close to the Bayon in the middle of Angkor Thom complex at the end of a raised walkway. A Hindu temple from the mid 11thC recently restored. Easily combined with visits to other nearby temples within walking distance.

My favorite temple here in Siem Reap.. The temple amazed me the courtyard on top was really great. It is close near other temples so you should definitley visit this if you are in the area near the other temples.
Nice Temple. All of these temples are pretty close so you should check this one out if you're nearby. You can climb up pretty high and get some nice pictures from above.

Simply beautiful.... I explored this temple alone... I was just walking around and saw this mountain-like temple.. i started walking through the "bridge" going to the temple... there were steel stairs built on the sides of that highly steep temple.. on top are courtyards and balconies and beautiful galleries... once on top, you will feel like you're a king!
Beautiful Temple. We went by tuk-tuk to Baphuon Temple and explored ourselves. Definitely worth visiting while in Siem Reap.
Might as well visit. We bought the 3 day pass to see and tour the temples, 1st day was awesome, 2nd day was great.. 3rd day was.. All I can say was you might as well see while you're there.

Temple run, anyone?. I think when the temple run creators saw this place, they were given the inspiration to start the game. Majestic view, but with lots of climbing, but worth it as the view from the top is truly spectacular. Who knows, you might reach the door to heaven.

Beautifully restored temple. It was my good luck that the Baphuon Temple was already reconstructed when I visited it last November 2013. The first stage is reached by a wood staircase with metal railings - better and more reassuring than the rickety narrow wood staircase at Phimeanakas. At the first level were long galleries with gopuras at certain points. It was also delightful to see bas-reliefs, some with animals, and the ubiquitous apsaras. The higher levels are reached by yet another steep wooden stairs. The view from the top is great, and the breeze keeps one cool even in the heat of a Cambodian afternoon. The galleries, though, are ruined, reduced only to columns. At the middle sits the ruined central tower, its four steps of laterite cordoned off. I went down and then, at the back, saw the rough outline of the massive reclining Buddha that was carved onto the back of the Hindu temple when it turned Buddhist.For its complexity and the great views, as well as being a prime example of monument restoration, Baphuon Temple is definitely worth a visit!
Similar to others but an excellent view. I didn't spend a lot of time wondering through the different areas of the temple. The draw is definitely the view over the manmade lakes.

Steep, Beautiful Climb. This temple was a highlight of the Angkor Thom area for me. The climb to the top is steep but the views are beautiful and it was not overly crowded at the top. Bring your camera and some water as I would consider myself in good shape but was definitely a little winded and parched as the climb is steep and the midday heat is intense.

Not for small children. If you have small children with you give this temple a pass. the reason being that children under 12 years are not alowed in the temple because of the steep climb. The guard at the gate will say no. You can still circle around the right and and see the temple from the bank on the side. Going this way also leads to a giant tree that makes good photo shot and then leadson to the back of Phimeanakas Old Gate. (Another place where children are not alowed because of the steep steps.

Just stunning!. This place is one of the highlights of the trip to Angkor Tom - so long as you can manage the climb to the top. Despite the signs of decay and the desperate need for restart of the restoration work, there is still so much to be seen and to be amazed by.

Another great temple.. There are unique carvings at the entrance of this temple. A steep ladder takes you to the top of the temple. However I missed the recling Buddha to the west of the temple. Lots of repairs are still needed.

Beware the steep climb!. The view is well-worth the climb, but if you have trouble with mobility, you should give this one a miss. A beautiful uncrowded visit, we visited just after sunrise in the morning mist.

Wonderful View from the Top. Baphuon Temples found in the Angkor Thom. You should not miss this temple because the view is absolutely amazing. There is a long bridge going into the front east gate and the ruins are fabulous. I cant explain in words you just have to go there. I would say this place is a must if you are visiting Siem Reap. You can also climb up three levels to get a view of everything around. You have to go!

A must when in Angkor Thom. From Bayon, do not miss this temple. The French were responsible for its conservation and there are plenty of explanations about how this was done. Alas, women who wear skimpy clothing or spaghetti blouses are not allowed to climb up this pyramid-like temple.

Fantastic temple but You will need goats feet to climb the steps!!!. A fantastic temple in the Angkor Thom complex with very steep steps, Monserrat steps have been put in with handrail but even these mean that if you have any walking problems forget it!!!. If you can make it to the top it is really worth while for the view. Baphoun has many carvings, arches and would have been amazing in its full glory. On the outer wall as you leave, there is a brilliant carving of Bhudda built in to the external wall, it is about 15 meters high and approx 50 long, not complete bug if you stand back you can marvel at the craftsmanship of the stone masons a thousand years ago with no mechanical help to build something on this scale, truly amazing. Don't forget to but your 3 day pass for the temples the day before you plan your trip, you can pick up the day before from the ticket office and save yourself 2 hrs min and avoid the crowds. The tickets are valid for 7 days and can be used for any 3 days within that time.
Worth visitng. You can't have enough of it. Ancient and so much to see. You need much more time to visit this temple and feel the time.

Worth the steep hike up. Visiting the Baphuon Temple was kind of eerie, as so much of the top portion reminded me of ruins in Greece. It is absolutely beautiful and a peaceful place to visit in the midst of the Angkor crowds.

Get away from the crowds. This large temple, only a short walk from Bayon, gets remarkably few visitors. It is worth climbing all the way to the top for the views and the story about how it was put back together after the era of the Khmer Rouge is fascinating. Get your driver to drop you at Bayon and meet up with him later opposite the terrace of the Leper King

Small but gorgeous temple. This temple was closed to the public last time I came. The unique causeway upon water was already a must see, now with the temple open, you can enjoy great view on the top, and a fully interesting discovery. The fact that there wasn't too much people visiting it was also a relief. I visited it in the evening and the lights were gorgeous through the multiple columned ways.
Climbing. NIce to get up. It is on the way to Banteay SreI, so a nice stop. The steps are not easy. Strangely the only temple that my 11 year old son was allowed to climb.

Missed it first time. Did the tour round bayan first time on bikes and completey missed Baphoun temple. Booked tuk tuk and went again, this time we got to it and its a gem, almost better than Bayan, less crowds.

worth the climb. take care and climb the stairs if you can. The view is worth it!
don't forget to look back to see the reclining buddha as you climb down

Nice history to the building of it.... Bauphon seemed just another temple at first, with lots of stairs to climb! Once up top it was worth it for the views and space to move around easily, but the most interesting aspect for me was the stories and the history of the building itself. Its a collection of rebuilds, including the reuse of some of the early stones to build the later dated Reclining Buddha on the rear side. A lovely causeway leading from the road way into the temple area.

Small temple. This is much smaller as compared to Bayon Temple. But nested in a lush surroundings. If you are physically fit, go for the climb within the temple, offers a bird's eye view of the surroundings.

very nice architecture. Loved all the stone work. I need to come back when it is not high season as the amount of tourists make it very hard to enjoy such wonders, pictures are hard to take without handfuls of people walking by and barely walking room on the platforms.

Steep Climb, Cool View. It doesn't take too long to explore this mountain-style temple in the Angkor Thom complex, but it is definitely worth giving a little time to. Be sure to walk fully around its exterior in addition to climbing it, as there is an unfinished reclining Buddha worked into the stone around the back side of the temple that might otherwise be missed. The view of the surrounding forest from the top is quite superb. During rainy season the surrounding moat makes the temple especially photogenic.
Ok, but .... It was not far from the Terrace of the Elephants, so we walked to it. I liked it but there was not much to see other than pyramid structure. Still interesting though.

Second Largest Temple in Angkor Thom Complex. Aside from Bayon, this is the most significant ruin in the Angkor Thom complex and, if you are going to see Bayon you should plan on stopping here as it is just across the road. There is a long, very nicely rebuilt, causeway leading from the road out to the temple. The temple is multi-tiered and warrants a bit of exploration, as long as you are up for the very steep stirs. Unfortunately, when we visited the very top level was closed. On the back side is a very large but poorly constructed reclining Buddha that was completed when the temple was renovated from a Hindu to Buddhist temple. This is the only temple we visited where we saw them enforcing the temple dress standards so, if you have been enjoying touring in your shorts be prepared for a dress change requirement when you get here.

my favorite pyramid. walking towards baphuon is like walking into a scene of stargate movie. very imposing and dark colors you feel like there is some strange music in the background. once there the stairs are extremely steep but the view from the top is very nice. my advice, walk slowly as you aproach it and suck the atmosphere. on your way down you can either go back to where you came from or walk for a couple hundered meters in the woods to reach phimeanakas

Great terrace. Something a little different.Something more compact.Something recently restored.Top tip?As you leave toward the rear, don't forget to turn round and try to pick out the "reclining Buddha" (lying on it's side) built in to the back wall.

Don't miss the Buddha lying at the side of the temple. Beautiful temple surrounded by a forest with mossy stones. There's a large Buddha lying on his side and its formed with the stones near the back. Nice to climb to the top and get a view of the surrounding areas as well.

A little different. Wonderfully restored approach to the temple and ease of access is a plus. The causeway approach is a wonderful entry with a pool of water on one side. One of the easiest temples take photos inside. A added bonus is he lack of other tourists meaning photos can be taken without others being in them.

The only way is up.. It's a short walk from Bayon to Baphuon Temple so we headed that way. It was cool to walk the long path that leads to the temple from the road. It's a three-tiered temple with the typical steep stairs and the view from the top was alright - don't expect to see an overhead view of too many things nearby, it's not "that" tall a structure. The climb, although steep, was not too difficult thanks to the railings. Just remember that going down is more tricky sometimes when the steps are narrow. It's still well worth the climb if you can manage it, for the satisfaction of getting the top.

its in Bayon Temple Area. Must do -if you do Bayon its not a long walk to this temple -If you only have one day In Siem Riep This is must do! Allow good 2 hours -has a steep climb via stairs but good views-also see lying buddha on rock face as you leave-you can get a guide book at site for $4-$5 and self guide thats what we did!
Another Great Temple. Loved the reclining Buddha built into one wall. Easy to miss, but very cool and massive. Lots of art and history to enjoy at this place. Go with a tour guide for best results.

Another great temple complex.... This is another one worth adding to the list! We really enjoyed walking around here, but once again, I would try to see as many as you can after sunrise at Angkor Wat so there are less tourists around!!

High temple mountain. This temple is still under restoration, since Khmer Rouge destroyed all the records about its structure, giving the experts many head-aches. No special carvings or bas-reliefs here, but great and rewarding views from atop if you manage your way to it through a very steep staircase, with the usual irregular steps typical of all temple mountains.A good reason for a visit is the manageable number of tourists here, you won't start screaming after a while trying to escape the temple and the hords of people.

not the original site. This site is a restored monument. Most of it is restored to give an impression of the original site. Therefore not in the same league as the rest of the monuments such as Bayon, Angkor Wat etc.
Vertigo inducing clamber. I have no head for heights but it is worth gritting your teeth and clambering to the top if only to see how many blocks remain to be put back as part of the restoration.

A puzzling dilemma from on high. This one had interesting grounds. Beautiful greenery surrounding the stones laid out during a pre-Khmer Rouge restoration project on the grounds outside. The work was resumed after that, but the KR had destroyed the records of the disassembly. So the restoration looks mostly done, but the original stones are still laid out in an unknown pattern on the grass.The tower is steep, but the wooden stairs over the stone steps make it easier to climb with the help of the guardrail (use it! The steep stairs are fairly vertiginous, and it would make your trip considerably less fun to tumble down them).Not very crowded, and worth the visit!

Huge temple-mountain. This is one huge temple-mountain in the heart of of Angkor Thom.It is sadly collapsed and in ruined condition.However,it is under a reconstruction programme. Note the unique animal carvings at the walkway entrance. They are similar to to the ones in west Mebon. Take note of the large reclining Buddha which differs from others you will encounter.

One of my favourites!. I spent 3 days going around all the temples at Angkor Tom and Angkor Wat and this was probably one of my favourites, mainly because of the elephants and the view from the 3 levels. Also it was easy to access and move around.

What a place to be 1000years ago. if you were part of this planet 1000 years ago, i think this place is where you'd want to be instead of anything civilized and occupied/ livable condition locations on this planet then.
Interesting Temple. Fabulous temple. Fully restored. Definitely worth a look. To climb up to heaven is hot and arduous but really is worth it.

Beautiful Baphuon. Baphuon temple is like a smaller version of Pre Rup. a smaller temple which serves as your stairs to Heaven. Its like it is built so you can view the magnificent view from above. If you are not afraid of heights, you can climb to the top of this temple. We sat for few minutes to enjoy such beautiful view in such a beautiful temple.

The Pyramid. Ba Phuon temple requires sleeved clothing and covered legs upon entrance so make sure you're dressed properly. The stairs leading to the top of this 3-tiered temple are very steep so be careful. But the view is rewarding from the top. Isn't it great that they finally reconstructed this last 2011? :)
Like a pyramid. this was my favorite site it was awe inspiring to just look at it. No visitors were allowed inside as there was work going on but I would love to go back to check it out.

Mountain temple. Huge Hindu temple largely restored. Long walkway to the entrance with water on both sides due to the rainy weather. Children below the age of 12 not allowed to enter and proper attire is required i.e clothes to cover arms and knees. Climb to the top for a view of the surroundings.

Largest 3-Dimensional Jigsaw Puzzle in the World. Seeing The Baphuon temple mountain (which was originally Hindu, then Buddhist) was a pleasant surprise on my Angkor Thom tour. While not as impressive as the nearby Bayon Temple, which is also part of Angkor Thom, it’s still an impressive sight. It was originally built in the 11th Century but large portions of it had collapsed over the centuries. When reconstruction began in the 20th Century, a 300 member team found 300,000 pieces of the temple surrounded by a jungle. It was like trying to put together a large jigsaw puzzle but they were successful and reconstruction is now complete. It’s a beautiful sight to see from afar but it’s worth climbing up the steep stairs to get a magnificent view of the surrounding jungle. Definitely make this part of your Angkor Thom tour.

A temple slowly growing in popularity. The Baphuon was originally a Hindu temple built in the 11th century but it was later converted to a Buddhist temple in the late 15th century. It is actually located within the walls of the ancient royal capital city of Angkor Thom and sits only about 200m northwest of the Bayon Temple.As the temple complex was built on sandy soil, much of the original structure had crumbled and collapsed and restoration work on the extensive ruins in later years have proven very difficult. Now, the officially restored temple draws a fairly good crowd and there are still many stone sculptures and bas reliefs on the walls and they are in fairly good condition. Although fully restored for viewing, there were still many stone slabs and blocks lying around the temple grounds waiting to be fitted into the big jigsaw puzzle. There’s no denying that the restoration work done thus far has been nothing short of fantastic and retains the many original features found in the ancient Khmer architecture.We visited the temple ruins during the rainy spell and both sides of the causeway leading to the temple complex were flooded with most of the vegetation under water. The temple building itself was a three-tier structure and built on a high square base and the highest level we ascended to was at least 30 meters high. Many visitors had decided against climbing up the extremely steep and high staircase to the top and were contented with exploring the lower level perimeter pathway, due the rain which was still drizzling the whole day. Although it was very dangerous, we took the challenge and climbed up the wet wooden steps but fortunately there were metal handrails all along the staircase to at least provide some sense of safety not only when ascending but also when descending by the same way later.After conquering the steep and wet staircase to the topmost level of the Baphuon, it was time to enjoy the breathtaking view from up there. Then it was time to descend and you can imagine the sense of relief when we touched the bottom of the stairs. Phew, what an experience!

One for mountain goats!. A really interesting temple that is not as heavily trafficked as Bayon and Ta Prom even though it is right next door to Bayon. Great architecture and worth a look even if you don't want to climb it.But the very steep steps are worth the effort. The view from the top is terrific
Love the elevated walkway. Adjacent to this structure is a lengthy elevated walkway that I love. Steep stairs/climbs and well-preserved archways make this structure worth a visit.

definitely worth the visit. This temple is not as popular as the others but definitely worth the visit. The walk along the bridge going to the entrance is surrounded by greenery. & the long climb up rewards you with a spectacular view. It can be quite hot going up the temple since it's mostly open (very little shade) so bring a cap/hat & lots of water. This temple also reminds me of the mobile game "temple run". You'll understand once you visit it.  *Visited this temple twice. It was crawling with tourists on a Saturday afternoon and practically empty on a Sunday afternoon. :)

Worth the climb. Spectacular views from the top but a bit of a steep climb in places. There are wooden steps through out rather than having to climb on the slippery stone but still some care needs to be taken. In various stages of repair but still worth the time.

This temple is recently re-open. This temple has the Royal Enclosure, Phimeanakas, the Elephant terrace and the Terrace of the Leper King. It's very big and beautiful you can climb on top and it has an amazing view, great for pictures. And every were you walk you find all kinds of ruins is breathtaking

newly recovered temple open for visit (lucky me, coming at right time), no shorts and no sleeveless, Not Allowed to enter if vio. interesting, huge and pretty temple, a long causeway to the temple is simply amazing. viewing from top is yet another stunning scenery. not many tourist most of the time except sunrise or sunset. tourist with shorts and sleeveless shirt are not allowed into this temple. but you can try another "exit" at the back of the temple to go in, if no choice.

BEAUTIFUL. The Baphuon is located in Angkor Thom, 200 meters northwest of the Bayon. But it is NOT crowded as expected - do not know why? But it made less troublesome to go up and down the stairs. It was also less noisy.

Worth the climb. Baphuon is not visited by as many people as the Bayon, which I don't quite understand because it's literally a few hundred metres away. But I guess that people who are on a tight schedule wouldn't probably bother to include most of the other temples of Angkor Thom. Therefore if you are willing to spend a bit of extra time or be thorough with your visit, Baphuon is a nice place. There are still plenty of people, just LESS people. Baphuon was the Royal Temple of the city, and they are strict about what you're wearing, so ensure your shoulders and knees are covered. They will not hesitate to turn you away if you are not properly covered. There are also a lot of incredibly steep steps but it's worth the climb and the scaffolding is safe, so take your time and enjoy the view once you get up the top.Also be careful walking through some of the low doorways, as I saw a lady hit her head and it looked quite painful. Remember that the people who used these temples were much more petite than many of us nowadays.

Simple yet Beautiful!. The touristy crowd doesn't come here, there is beautiful lush greenery surrounding this temple, and it is mounted in 4 distinct layers, its a giddy climb all the way to the top. The heat almost killed us, but we enjoyed this temple despite that.

Another beautiful temple. The temples of Bayon, Baphoun, Terrace of Elephants and Terrace of the Leper King are situated right next to one another (it's one tuk-tuk or cycle stop) and it is worth spending 2-3 hours seeing all of them. All the temples/terraces look different. The walk to the Baphoun over a bridge is amazing! Beyond the Baphoun, there is a path through the forest to two lesser-known jungle temples, which cannot be missed! You see trees and stones growing together in a way so strange, that it takes you away right to some magical 'Inca'-like universe!
Huge Temple. Baphuon is a huge temple, it has 3 levels. There is a quite long bridge as a path to the temple, on each side of the bridge there must have been a pond, but's it's almost dry now.

Called a "temple mountain" by my tour guide. It is a steep and long climb up narrow stairs to the top of this temple, but the views from the top are fantastic. Best to wear a hat as the sunlight is very hot and intense.

Nice. The Baphuon is a temple at Angkor, Cambodia. It is located in Angkor Thom, northwest of the Bayon. Built in the mid-11th century, it is a three-tiered temple mountain built as the state temple of Udayadityavarman II dedicated to the Hindu God Shiva.

Probably the most spectacular Angkor temple in its time. The renovation of Baphuon Temple was interrupted by the civil war and, having taken 300,000 pieces apart the plans were destroyed so the challenge now is to restore those pieces...Even so there is a lot to see here, it is reputed to have been the most spectacular of the Angkor temples in its time and with a little imagination that is quite possible. The only way to do justice to this site is to climb and all the stairs are very steep - good shoes and take it slowly.There is a small set of display panels showing restoration work and how the temple may have looked - worth spending a bit of time over.There is a large unfinished reclining Buddha carved into the western wall at the second level, from the waist up it is clear but nothing much exists of the lower body.There are some interesting inside walkways.Our guide skipped this site on the first day of our tour so two of us went back on our own a day later and we were both glad we did - I would say do not miss it, but take your imagination along with those good shoes.

Worth the trip!. Must obey the dress code! covering with shawl doesn't help at all.I was rejected the first time, went back the other morning and it was closed. Lucky it open again after I visited Terrence of Leper King!the view from on top is awesome, you are able to walk around it to get different view. Climbing all the way up and coming down is scary too. That era people must have not afraid of heights at all!Get a guide to explain everything to you, else you will be feeling so lost up there.

Just Amazing. Baphuon was built in the middle of the 11th Century and is located 200 meters north-west of the Bayon. This single temple mountain sanctuary is situated on a high base which symbolizes Mount Meru. A highlight of the temple is the bas reliefs which are different from most others as they are carved in small stone squares set above one another on the temple walls. Much of this Temple has collapsed or been dismantled and is still under going intensive restoration. Worth the steep climb, amazing views!Allow about 1 hour to see the Baphuon.

Beautiful. Another one of the must-see sites in the Angkor region. Baphuon is a temple dedicated to Shiva and has engendered its own architectural style. Built on multiple levels, it has suffered the ravages of time but is still a beautiful sight to behold.See it.

Steep stairs. We visited here after going to see the sunrise at Angkor Wat, then Bayon. Amazing carvings as at other temples. The stairs to the top and quite steep and narrow but there is a handrail. The view from the top is worthwhile. Coming down the other side are another set of steep stairs which also have a handrail. Wear good footwear, cover knees and shoulders, take hat and water. We had a private guide to explain features and the history to us, quite necessary I think at all temples.

Amazing temple in Angkor Thom - climb to the top. Another amazing temple - there is a long way to access the temple. Take your time to fully explore the temple, around 2-3 hours. There are steep stairways up the temple and also steep stairways down the temple. The view from the top is spectacular.

Really enjoyed it. The view over the water towards the temple is breathtaking. I enjoyed this temple a lot despite all the steep climbing to get to the very top...it's a bit scary to climb down as the steps are very narrow and steep but worth the effort as you get rewarded with lovely views.

Beautiful Temple. This is one of the temple I liked the most.Firstly because it is beautiful but also because there weren't as much tourist there as everywhere else - because you have to wear over-knee and over-shoulder clothes already to get in to the temple. Take some time and rest in the shadow of Baphuon Temple or read the reliefs around it. It is beautiful!
It will tire and scare you. The only thing I remember about this temple is that it's a grueling climb and a frightening descent.
Exercise. The stairs however are very steep and hard to get up and even more difficult to get down, but once you are there you can see Angkor Thom. Go and just do it !!!

A little disappointing. After having seen many other temples in Angkor, Baphuon, although well restored by the French, hasn't much extras to offer. You can walk around the temple and look for the lying Bouddha at the west side.

Worth the climb!. Make sure to go all the way to the top. The view is breathtaking! Stay for a couple of minutes on top just to relax and take everything in. Go early as well to avoid the large chinese tour groups.

Climb the steps for a wonderful view. We visited the Baphoun Temple immediately after the Bayon Temple and whilst not nearly as beautiful it is very atmospheric, probably because there were very few tourists around when we arrived in the late afternoon.Largely overgrown, there are some incredibly steep steps up to the top. Halfway up, I started to regret the climb, but the view from the top was beautiful over the tree tops. Climbing down was not quite as frightening as I feared, but if you do not like heights it may be helpful to just concentrate on each step at a time.

Brilliant site which is surprisingly less recommended. Another fantastic Angkor complex site. Baphuon is located within Angkor Thom and has only recently been renovated. The causeway access to the Temple is a nice introduction to the Temple. Once inside there is information about the Temple and the restoration. Then you can climb to the top of this Temple but be warned It is a steep climb, especially in the heat, to get to the very top though well worth it. Equally I would recommend visiting if you were only able to partially climb the Temple. As said by others, the back of the Temple is not to be missed. There is a fantastic reclining Buddha built in to the wall at the back, It is a wonderful image. I would say this is a must see within the Angkor complex.

Get ready for the climb.. Baphuon is a recently restored temple in the Angkor Thom complex. It is open to the public to scale to its summit. If you want to see how Baphuon looked like before restoration, there are information boards put up at the first level of the temple as you enter through the temple's eastern gopura and across the raised causeway. Do not miss reading these boards as they give a mountain of information about the amazing restoration process and just gives you the heaviness and the complexity of putting this jigsaw of a temple together --- from the mound of dirt it started from to the temple you climb today. Outstanding difference! They even placed what the temple looked like during the Angkor Thom era (I've also uploaded it for your wonderment). After seeing this picture, you will surely go... I would've loved to see this temple in its fullness back during those day. A fair warning to visitors: even if they have built stairs over the damaged original stairs, these stairs are just as steep as the original ones. It will really test your nerves! The authorities have placed tour routes which give the visitor a route to follow around the temple. You may opt to follow this or not. However, you must at least follow the signs saying if the flight of stairs are for going up or down. It's just basic courtesy to the one going up or down and basic rule-abiding. If you conquered your fears and went up the whole temple mountain, savor your victory by looking at the view from the top. It is not really a great view. It's just tree tops and a view of the causeway and gopura below. Remember the whole area around the temple is forested so other sites will be blocked from view by the trees. Still, savor your victory. It is one of the hardest temple mountains to scale --- you had two flights of steep stairs to go up and there's still the way down. If you go down the first of the two flight of stairs down, before you go to the second, detour to your left and go outside the corridor through the windows on your left. After jumping out of this window, go left again and check out the carvings near the stairs from which you went down from. You will see carvings on the walls of typical animals: birds, deer, horses, etc. It's quite unique since I never saw any of these types of carvings at other temples. If you're done, go down the second flight of stairs.Leave at the back of the temple. Again, you will be seeing information boards, but this time it tells you about a unique sight of this temple. The whole back side of the temple is a figure of a reclining Buddha albeit not initially discernible! Another complexity of the restoration process! Wonderful indeed! DO NOT MISS! It's a unique feature unseen in other Angkor temples. I went to this temple a little past noontime. There were very few people scaling this temple so it made it less troublesome to go up and down the stairs. It was also less noisy. But, it was too hot. Remember to put on some sunscreen first! Do not miss this temple! It's the hardest to scale. It has unique carvings. It has a reclining Buddha carved to the back side of the temple. That's three enough reasons to visit this temple mountain.

"More of the same", anyone? :). This is a rather new addition to the touristic hype of Siem Reap, and what can I say - "more of the same" sums it up pretty much.There are many, many, many steps to climb, and while the view from the top IS nice, once you've visited Angkor Wat, you can skip this one for sure.A 30-minute visit is over the top for this temple.

Dress Properly. They didn't let me in because my attire was a bit inappropriate. No hurt feelings though. That I completely understand and respect. Baphuon is still an active Theravada Buddhist temple. I should've brought a long cover-up skirt to be allowed to climb this beautiful temple. I'll be more appropriate next time :)))

Climb every mountain... temple.. Don't miss this! This isn't in most of the guidebooks (yet), and has a surprisingly low rating in Trip Advisor, presumably because this temple was recently opened to the public, after restoration work was completed some 2 years ago. I would have missed this, had my tour guide not worked this into the itinerary. What many don't know is that Baphuon is older than Angkor Wat. The view from the top is breathtaking. Best time to see it is now, when the tourist hordes haven't yet discovered it. Couple of helpful tips: (1) Make sure you wear comfortable shoes with a good grip, if you plan to scale up this temple. Baphoun is a mountain temple. Expect to walk up several flights of steep stairwells. The view of Angkor Thom once you reach the top, is worth the effort. (2) Heed the advice, offered by other reviewers, on appropriate attire; i.e. shoulders and knees must be covered. The dress code is strictly enforced.
Very tall and magnificent. This temple is very big and get ready to go up stairs. but once you are there yo can see the whole Angkor Thom.
one more !. by this time you must have seen all the great temples and therefore this one wud seem not much different... but if you have had the chance and time to see this , its a good visit !

Ladies cover your legs and shoulders. I was not allowed to enter this temple as I had my shoulders showing, there was another lady I saw who couldnt enter as her shorts were above her knees.
My husband still went in and said it was fantastic so next time we go to Siem Reap I will make sure I wear a long shirt instead.

couldnt take children. I just wanted to share with everyone that you cannot take children under 12 years old into the temple or pregnant women. It must be dangerous. Just for everyone to consider. I have given it an average review only because I never got to see it as Im travelling with my 6 year old daughter.

A 'Cambodian' Pyramid. The newly look of Baphuon after long person of preservation by French government. Beautiful site in the Bayon complex. When you visiting the Terrace of Elephant then do quick visit to this monument. But many tourists visit this site.

Spectacular. This is the tallest of the temples situated on a high base. We were lucky to visit Baphuon last year, a day after it was reopened in an official ceremony after restoration and was allowed to climb right up to the top most level where a door frame stands. The time around the top level was off limits. Be prepared to climb up steep steps for a view that is truly spectacular!

After a long restoration..finally it's open!. This temple took very long to restore. Its pyramidal shape is unique compared to the rest. But due to its shape, the stairs are steep. If not for wooden steps it will be much worse.

A steep climb. Another amazing temple populated by the Orange smilley monks.Watch the monks when no one is around and they are very funny. A sly cigaret or two.The temple is still under resurection but looks amazing a great place to sit and chill.y

Another gem, but make sure you're prepared.... The restoration of the Baphuon has take decades but the wait and many interruptions have been worth it. This is undoubtedly one of the great sites at Angkor; the most Pyramid-like of all the temples. The modern steps up to the top (almost) on the north side of the temple offer a great view. You descend by an equally steep set of steps on the south side.But one important warning: kids under 12, pregnant women and inappropriately dressed people are not allowed in (bare shoulders seemed particularly offensive - carry a scarf in your bag and it will keep them happy). The restriction on kids does, sort of, make sense.....the climb to the top is precipitous. However, there's a question about whether - with appropriate warnings and all the doubtless legal caveats - that should be the responsibility of responsible adults. Therse is not upper age limit but I know that I'd back a 10 year old over an 80 year old to get to the top and down again.

Steep Stairs to get to the Top. Children under 12 are not allowed in this Temple as there is steep climb to the top. The view after one reaches the temple top is amazing and worth experiencing the vastness of the place. We enoyed are brief visit to this temple.

Your daily dose of exercise. Really steep stairs but once you are up, the view can be breathtaking. Try locating the face of the reclining buddha at the back of the temple. It's not very much visible as the reclining buddha was never completed. Nevertheless, it's worth the visit as it will be on your after exiting Bayon.

Steep climb to the top. This temple is nice as you can get on top of it and get some great pictures of the beautiful pathway which leads into it. The stairs however are very very steep and hard to get up and even more difficult to get down. They are strangely strict on their dress code here and didn't allow my girlfriend in with short pants. This is odd as all other temples didn't care. Something to consider.

Hidden Treasure. The Baphoun wasnt mentioned to us by guides or guidebooks and we only found it as we were at the Terrace of the Elephant king but it is amazing! A long (perhaps 400m?) pillared walkway approach then a multi tiered large temple surrounded by outlying pools and smaller structured. On the rear face is a massive (if now i poor repair) reclining Bhudda. A true hidden Treasure! Beautiful

A real great temple. Oh dear, it is definately a great temple, or else, what took it so long to be restored? Now, Dec 2010, not yet complete.The temple was built around 1060 A.D., one hundred years before Angkor Wat. The temple, said, measured 50 m high, 130 x 103 m on the base, with 420 x 125 m enclosure, and a 200 m long causeway was built to connect the temple from the entrance gopura. According to my guidebook, the upper part of the temple fall because of the basement of the temple cannot support the weight of the whole temple. This temple is clustered together (or to be more accurate, stick together) with Terrace of Elephants, Terrace of the Leper King, and the Royal Temple. It is just 400 m from Bayon. So, although it might take more time for the temple to reclaim its former glory, it will be no harm for us to stop by and take a visit on it.http://bettyandlingshing.blogspot.com/2010/12/phnom-bakheng-and-baphuon.html

Still hoarded up. This is within Angkor Thom a relatively short walk away from the Terrace of Elephants. Guide books will tell you that this temple would have been one of the greatest. However restoration works are still under way and you will see hoardings. It was last year and it still is as of the end of August 2008.
